componenttext: I thought I was pretty expansive with Michael. I don't know what you mean about splitting up, splitting up the balance sheet further. I mean, we have built cash. We said a year ago that these were -- that the right strategy was to push away from overpriced acquisitions, to build cash, et cetera. We've done that. We're very pleased with the condition of our balance sheet. And I don't really understand your question.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess, you started the call talking about $4.5 billion of potential liquidity positions you to do larger things if you split the company into, I guess, 2/3, 1/3 or something along those lines. Each of the entities will just have less capital to wo
componenttext: Well, I guess, you started the call talking about $4.5 billion of potential liquidity positions you to do larger things if you split the company into, I guess, 2/3, 1/3 or something along those lines. Each of the entities will just have less capital to work with. And then your development projects for each entity would obviously be a larger part of the balance sheet.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Whatever we do in terms of hiving off the business or splitting up, or separating, or deconglomerating, each business will have appropriate balance sheets to accomplish their missions. We did that very carefully with UE. We know how to do that. It's cruci
componenttext: Whatever we do in terms of hiving off the business or splitting up, or separating, or deconglomerating, each business will have appropriate balance sheets to accomplish their missions. We did that very carefully with UE. We know how to do that. It's crucial to the success of the businesses. The way we look upon it, we are still an owner -- the way I look upon it, we are still an owner of UE. We kept our shares, and we need -- we want UE to thrive just like we want Vornado to thrive, and any children or grandchildren that might come out of Vornado will be in a similar condition. And by the way, we do have the mothership balance sheet to do almost anything that we want to. I would tell you that while we do have an enormous amount of liquidity intentionally, we consider our silly stock price to be our #1 target. I would also tell you that -- just a comment about the balance sheet. I mean, Steve Theriot said that our consolidated debt-to-EBITDA ratio was 7 point...

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
Vornado Realty Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: 7.5, I look at it slightly differently. The way I look at it, if you normalized our cash, so saying that we would always have $500 million of cash, so that's a $1.5 billion of excess cash, so to speak. And you take Skyline, which is grossly overleveraged,
componenttext: 7.5, I look at it slightly differently. The way I look at it, if you normalized our cash, so saying that we would always have $500 million of cash, so that's a $1.5 billion of excess cash, so to speak. And you take Skyline, which is grossly overleveraged, it has almost $700 million of debt with negligible income. If you take those 2 out, the number is -- the debt-to-EBITDA number goes down to 6.2.

componenttext: Okay. And then for my follow-up. I think you said you're over 50% sold at 220 Central Park South. Last quarter, I think you said 53% to 54%. Can you just give us an update on where you guys are on actual sales?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: We choose not to. I have said that the market is slowing. It's slowing for everybody. It's slowing a little bit less for us, but, of course, it's slowing for us as well. For competitive reasons, I mean, what we have said is we are 53% or 54%, whatever fro
componenttext: We choose not to. I have said that the market is slowing. It's slowing for everybody. It's slowing a little bit less for us, but, of course, it's slowing for us as well. For competitive reasons, I mean, what we have said is we are 53% or 54%, whatever from last -- we're not going backwards from last quarter, of course. We are well more than half sold. We've covered our costs. We're fully financed. We're going to -- we're 2-odd years away from delivery, and I -- it's a cyclical business. And for competitive reasons, I don't think it's good for our business to give the kind of details, minute details. It doesn't help us. It hurts us competitively in the market. But we're in great shape. It's the premier project. Everybody in the marketplace knows it's the premier project. We are in great shape, and we are totally and completely out of financial risk.

componenttextpreview: Steve, just first question is going to Skyline. Can you just remind us of the historic tax protection and what Vornado has as far as if there's recourse on the $700 million? I mean, it would seem as far as just quick bang for the buck, if Skyline is the d
componenttext: Steve, just first question is going to Skyline. Can you just remind us of the historic tax protection and what Vornado has as far as if there's recourse on the $700 million? I mean, it would seem as far as just quick bang for the buck, if Skyline is the drag, and that's been clearly an issue over the past number of years, just sending the keys back would be a win not only for the market cap of Vornado but also just the -- or I should say in the reverse, but for the fundamentals of the D.C. portfolio, which in fact would help the market cap. So can you just remind us what the ability of -- for Vornado just walk away from that asset?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, I was wondering if you could just elaborate a little bit on the 1 and 2 Penn Plaza projects. And I realize you haven't cemented specific dollar figures. But can you kind of help us frame out the capital cost that would be needed in order to, as you
componenttext: Steve, I was wondering if you could just elaborate a little bit on the 1 and 2 Penn Plaza projects. And I realize you haven't cemented specific dollar figures. But can you kind of help us frame out the capital cost that would be needed in order to, as you said, kind of double the rents on these buildings?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's premature, but it's certainly a fair question. So first off, when you think about it, those 2 buildings are giant. One is 1.5 million, 1.6 million square feet. The other one is 2.5 million, 2.6 million, 2.7 million square feet. So in total, they are
componenttext: It's premature, but it's certainly a fair question. So first off, when you think about it, those 2 buildings are giant. One is 1.5 million, 1.6 million square feet. The other one is 2.5 million, 2.6 million, 2.7 million square feet. So in total, they are really -- they're sort of like kissing cousins and they comprise 4.12 million square feet in total. So it's massive, number one. Number two is they sit right on top of the busiest train station in North America. So that's unbelievable. There are no other buildings that share that honor, so to speak. And number three is that they are right in the center, right at the bull's eye of what we call and the marketplace calls the New West Side. So it's a tremendous opportunity. Now having said that, one of the real opportunities is that the buildings are sufficiently large so that the owner of the building -- and they are in one ownership, so there's lots of benefits to that. We can move tenants back and forth between the 2 buildings. If a tenant needs overflow space or expansion space and we don't have it in the building that they are in, we can move -- we can pick that up in an adjacent building, although that's interesting, because the buildings historically are always full. The second thing is we can afford to put an amenity complex into those 4-plus million square foot buildings that are not economic even for 0.5 million or 1 million foot building, which are also large buildings. And the population of those buildings that will be coursing through the spaces is also enormous, and we can put food offerings and even delivery of food into the complexes. So there's lots of different ideas that we have, many of which are being taken from what the tech industry is doing on their big huge campuses. Now in terms of what they're going to cost, they are both going to be co-mingled with improvements which will affect Penn Station and the neighborhood. Now what I mean by that is, is that we are confident that we will -- that the 33rd Street will be closed, and that gives a great opportunity, and both of the buildings front on 33rd Street, to create entrances into the station, to create skylights and light into the stations and what have you. So it's very hard to -- which I've already said we are going to participate in, or at least we're going to participate in this RFP with all of -- enthusiastically and in a huge way. So it's hard to separate them. Now Two Penn, we've already said publicly that our plans are to completely skin the building, to take the skin of the building off and replace it with a new skin, which will have aesthetic consequences, of course; but more importantly than that, it will allow the, what are old-fashioned punched windows to grow to be almost, not quite, but almost floor-to-ceiling windows, which have large breadth and make the building looked like it was built recently, which will enormously increase the market value of the building. The skin will also involve the entrance on Seventh Avenue to Penn Station, which is directly under our building, which is the main entrance to Penn Station. So there is lots of things going on here, which are enormously exciting. The Penn, the One Penn building will be more like in cost a conventional transformation and upgrade that we would do, more expensive because it's twice the size. The Two Penn will be much more expensive because it involves a total re-skinning . So it's too early. It's premature to put a number on that. But I can tell you that we are unbelievably excited about the opportunity.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I guess, second question, follow-up. Just any comments on Hotel Penn? I know you've obviously said that the hotel market saturated with supply. This is kind of a low-RevPAR hotel. Just as you think about transforming that marketplace, how far off in
componenttext: Okay. I guess, second question, follow-up. Just any comments on Hotel Penn? I know you've obviously said that the hotel market saturated with supply. This is kind of a low-RevPAR hotel. Just as you think about transforming that marketplace, how far off in the future is the renovation of Hotel Pennsylvania?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know. The hotel business is soft. We're taking our lumps at the Hotel Pennsylvania. It's very cyclical and very volatile. And over the years of our ownership, it's gone up and down repeatedly. We are in a down-cycle now. So that's step #1. Step #2
componenttext: I don't know. The hotel business is soft. We're taking our lumps at the Hotel Pennsylvania. It's very cyclical and very volatile. And over the years of our ownership, it's gone up and down repeatedly. We are in a down-cycle now. So that's step #1. Step #2 is that we have not been able to land a tenant that would justify razing the building -- an office tenant, and building an office building, and I don't know whether we even think that that's likely or not. So the answer is, is the Hotel Pennsylvania's time will come. Right now, we are focusing more on One Penn and Two Penn across the street. And so I think that's my answer. I know -- if you guys have -- you have been focused on the Hotel Pennsylvania for a while, and we have not yet resolved what the right business plan is for that.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, from your prepared remarks, it seems pretty clear that you're still seeing robust leasing activity today. I expect you've heard concerns and commentary from the New York peers regarding job and rent growth later this year and noncore properties may
componenttext: David, from your prepared remarks, it seems pretty clear that you're still seeing robust leasing activity today. I expect you've heard concerns and commentary from the New York peers regarding job and rent growth later this year and noncore properties may be repricing lower. I'm just curious, are you expecting those kind of changes yourselves down the road? And, I guess, related to this, Mitchell, do you have similar concerns with respect to asset valuation in the D.C. Metro?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, John, no listen. As it relates to New York, I think Steve said that we haven't really seen any real, quote, hiccups at this point in time, and I think that's absolutely accurate. So the pipeline that we have is extraordinarily full. We have seen, w
componenttext: First, John, no listen. As it relates to New York, I think Steve said that we haven't really seen any real, quote, hiccups at this point in time, and I think that's absolutely accurate. So the pipeline that we have is extraordinarily full. We have seen, what I'll call is, in 1 or 2 very, very limited instances on some small deals, companies effectively, as Steve mentioned, hit the pause button. But generally, I will tell you, as we looked at fourth quarter, the actual activity, as well as everything that we're working on here in the first quarter, I think I used the word our pipeline remained strong, it does -- so I got my leasing guys sitting in lease negotiations round the clock on some very big deals, and what's interesting is a number of those deals that we're working on once again, and I think this is really important, represent expansions by companies in New York. It's not just the musical chair business. As I said, last year, some 750,000-plus square feet of our deals were real growth to the city. What's fascinating is notwithstanding some of the clamor in the financial markets, we really have continued to see the guys that have good businesses, good business platforms continuing to look to grow in the city.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, we are very constructive. We believe that business continues to be good. We, as I said in my remarks, we're looking over our shoulders because we're seasoned warriors and we know that this kind of volatility make decision-makers and counterparties j
componenttext: John, we are very constructive. We believe that business continues to be good. We, as I said in my remarks, we're looking over our shoulders because we're seasoned warriors and we know that this kind of volatility make decision-makers and counterparties just pause for a second and say, "What's going on here," which is only natural and only expected, okay? So the first thing is we see no deterioration in the New York Office business. That's step one. What's going to happen 9 months or a year from now, that's another question, and we see no basis upon which to believe that 9 months or a year from now, the New York Office business will be any different than it is today. So that's step one. I mean, obviously, if there's a huge deterioration in the economy, all bets are off, okay? So that's step 1. Step 2 is, is that New York benefits from an enormously diverse business community, and there are at any given time certain sectors which are expanding and certain sectors are contracting. We see no sign that people like Amazon and Facebook or their ilk are doing anything other than full steam ahead and expanding aggressively. So a lot of what happens to the individual companies is a function of the mix of their assets and to which segment of the office market they cater to. So I can only tell you that we stand by our remarks that we think business is good, and we believe that it will continue to be good for the foreseeable future.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And I guess, the second piece of my question with respect to asset valuations. Are you guys -- are you cautious on that front looking forward, or any reason to expect any movement in cap rate?
componenttext: That's helpful. And I guess, the second piece of my question with respect to asset valuations. Are you guys -- are you cautious on that front looking forward, or any reason to expect any movement in cap rate?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: The answer is sure. The first thing is, I think some -- the secondary assets, I can't vouch for what the pricing is on secondary assets. For prime assets, we see no diminution in pricing. We do see that there are fewer bidders than at the hysterical top o
componenttext: The answer is sure. The first thing is, I think some -- the secondary assets, I can't vouch for what the pricing is on secondary assets. For prime assets, we see no diminution in pricing. We do see that there are fewer bidders than at the hysterical top of the market, maybe whatever that was, a year ago, or whatever, and so we think that the big thing is that -- and I sort of said this in my remarks, this swoon, I'll call that a swoon for the moment for want of a better word, and the volatility in the capital markets, I believe and most commentators believe, will cause an extension of below-interest-rate, easy-money environment that we have found ourselves in for years and years now. And it's very hard to understand how, with the treasury at 1.8% today, that cap rates can go above go above 4.5%, let's say, into the 5s and 6s. So the interest rate environment and the wall of liquidity, which still exists, is an anchor on keeping pricing firm. The next part of it is, is that it's not random that we and our colleagues operate in New York City, which we consider to be the magnet for both domestic and international capital to invest in real estate. And also, it's when -- history has shown that when there is volatility in the capital markets, after the initial jitters are over, this real estate becomes an extraordinarily important store of value that has over decades and decades. Michael Franco is in the room, who's our Chief Investment Officer. Do you have anything else to add to that?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Look, I think the only thing I would say is that buyers that are more driven by financing, as Steve alluded to earlier, where the cost of borrowing has gone up and more impacted, and so those transitional assets, I think we'll see a little bit of near
componenttext: No. Look, I think the only thing I would say is that buyers that are more driven by financing, as Steve alluded to earlier, where the cost of borrowing has gone up and more impacted, and so those transitional assets, I think we'll see a little bit of near-term softening. But in terms of the Class A assets, the demand for that in the pricing, I don't think is going to change much.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Also, John, I put into my remarks the example of what we did in financing 770 Broadway intentionally because I think it's an extraordinary execution. So let me just discuss it again. What we did there was it's a 1.1 million square-foot building, which has
componenttext: Also, John, I put into my remarks the example of what we did in financing 770 Broadway intentionally because I think it's an extraordinary execution. So let me just discuss it again. What we did there was it's a 1.1 million square-foot building, which has extraordinary tenants. By the way, it's a mature building, which is my way of saying it's -- basically it's a Wanamaker's department store, so it has enormous floor place, high ceilings, great windows. It's a terrific building in a terrific spot, although it is not anywhere -- it is not by any stretch a new chrome and -- a steel-and-glass building, anyway. So we financed it. We refinanced the $350-odd million loan in the 5s for $700 million, and we did it on a floating-rate basis, and they floated at LIBOR 1.75, and then we swapped the floating rate to fixed. So we have an extensive capital markets team here, and we analyzed every different option in terms of both duration of loan and floating fixed, et cetera. And so we basically have borrowed a -- made it a 5-year fixed loan. It's actually technically a 4.5-year fixed, which is another whole tale. We swapped it for 4.5 years, and the rate is 2.56. Now that's an extraordinary rate for a high-quality building. It's really hard to see how cap rates rise with that kind of finance available. In fact, this may sound crazy to you, cap rates may well decline a little bit. So there you have it.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very interesting. I guess, just one last question. There've been rumbling in the press over the last handful of months that you guys are exploring, repurposing the office space at 666 Fifth. I was just wondering if you guys could comment on this, w
componenttext: That's very interesting. I guess, just one last question. There've been rumbling in the press over the last handful of months that you guys are exploring, repurposing the office space at 666 Fifth. I was just wondering if you guys could comment on this, whether such a plan in the works or anything you could say?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: The answer is it's premature. 666, and I -- this same exact question came up last call, and basically, what I said last call still stands for this call. The asset is a grand asset. It's right in the heart of Fifth Avenue. We own the retail strip, which is
componenttext:
The answer is it's premature. 666, and I -- this same exact question came up last call, and basically, what I said last call still stands for this call. The asset is a grand asset. It's right in the heart of Fifth Avenue. We own the retail strip, which is Uniqlo and Hollister, which is 3 quarters of the block front. We do not own the Zara store, which is their flagship store, which is owned by Zara. So we own the retail. The office building, we own half the retail together with a co-venture partner -- I'm sorry, half the office building together with a co-venture partner, the building has a very hefty loan on it. So it's basically almost a -- let me leave it that way, has a very hefty loan. So the partners have been exploring options, which center around the concept that the land unencumbered by building is worth more than the existing assets that are on the building, on the land. Said another way, the highest and best use for that property is not an office building. So there's been lots of exploratory thinking about what is the right thing, the right business plan with that asset. And I think that's where -- it's premature. It's an unbelievable asset and location, and I think that's what I have to say. 
I apologize to everybody for the duration of this call, but we felt we had a lot of things that we wanted to say.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question came from Michael Lewis from SunTrust.
componenttext: And our next question came from Michael Lewis from SunTrust.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: You delivered on your goal to end the year with nearly $2 billion in cash. Good leverage and liquidity. But if you had to guess, do you think that some of that dry powder eventually gets used to fund opportunistic acquisitions? In other words, maybe value
componenttext: You delivered on your goal to end the year with nearly $2 billion in cash. Good leverage and liquidity. But if you had to guess, do you think that some of that dry powder eventually gets used to fund opportunistic acquisitions? In other words, maybe values are peaking or opportunities will shake loose? And I feel like I'm kind of getting mixed messages on that, not just from you. Or do you think that capital eventually gets driven into opportunities in your existing portfolio, which we've talked a lot about?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: First of all, we're in a great position, intentionally so. So having cash in this kind of an environment is -- having cash in any environment is good. Having cash in this kind of an environment is even better. So #1 is we're delighted with our balance she
componenttext: First of all, we're in a great position, intentionally so. So having cash in this kind of an environment is -- having cash in any environment is good. Having cash in this kind of an environment is even better. So #1 is we're delighted with our balance sheet. We're delighted with our cash position and our financial flexibility. We think it's a very important strategic competitive advantage to have. Having said that, the options for our cash and liquidity are, as you just said, internal or external. Now external is acquisitions. So it would have to be a hell of an acquisition to be a better buy than, for example, our stock price, so having said that, although unique acquisitions will get our attention even at a silly stock price. So we have external opportunities. We have nothing in mind. And I'd -- we would be -- it's a stretch to even think what would make us wade into this marketplace with heavy debt. Now we turn to internal. Internal is 2 things: our stock and the vast array of internal capital opportunities we have to invest capital at, we believe, high returns in our existing portfolio and with our existing assets and inventory. So those are the options. It's premature to say what we will do. Clearly, we are going to invest internally every single internal project that we have on our plate: Penn Station, the Chelsea buildings, some development in -- limited development in Washington. Every single one of those will get its fair share of capital and will be done. Anything else is discretionary, and it's premature.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. My second question is about D.C., and you touched on this again a little bit. As far as Skyline, assuming you don't put back the keys, the occupancy's already quite low. What is kind of the future hold for those assets to kind of turn those around?
componenttext: Okay. My second question is about D.C., and you touched on this again a little bit. As far as Skyline, assuming you don't put back the keys, the occupancy's already quite low. What is kind of the future hold for those assets to kind of turn those around? And then in Crystal City, I realize the occupancy is up. But maybe you could talk a little bit about the economics there and if you're really making money on those leases. Is that kind of where that 0 to $4 million of core D.C. EBITDA is coming from? Or is that elsewhere?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mitchell, you want to take that?
componenttext: Mitchell, you want to take that?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So with respect to Skyline, Skyline is in a challenged position today. Historically, Skyline has attracted certain government agencies and has had significant follow-on in terms of government contractors, and there's obviously been some dislocation
componenttext: Sure. So with respect to Skyline, Skyline is in a challenged position today. Historically, Skyline has attracted certain government agencies and has had significant follow-on in terms of government contractors, and there's obviously been some dislocation in that market. So I think that Skyline is going to take some time to recover. The vacancy is going to drop another 500 basis points or so this year through some scheduled expirations, particularly contractors who won't renew, so...

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Occupancy will decline.
componenttext: Occupancy will decline.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Occupancy will decline. And so I think that's basically the situation, and it's really a -- it will take time till we either find the right engine or the right growth engine that will occupy space there, that will have the follow-on effect that it will re
componenttext: Occupancy will decline. And so I think that's basically the situation, and it's really a -- it will take time till we either find the right engine or the right growth engine that will occupy space there, that will have the follow-on effect that it will return to the situation that it was in. So obviously very close proximity to the Pentagon and will make sense over the long run. We just can't predict at this point how long it'll take and given some of the other vacancies in the marketplace. With respect to Crystal City, I think that we're constructive on Crystal City, and we're happy with the progress that we've made in terms of leasing. It's obviously a competitive market, but nonetheless, we are constructive with the progress that we've made in terms of moving a significant amount of the inventory. At this point in time, we're not moving our rents up. We certainly think that the rents and concessions have bottomed. So we'll keep close eye and see how that moves off into the future. And with respect to the core business increases, I think it's sprinkled around the whole portfolio. I can't give you a specific answer on the phone today.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let's see. Well, the term loan -- the $550 million that was outstanding on the revolver at year-end of was repaid in early January out of proceeds of cash plus transactions that closed in January. It would be a struggle for me to actually match for you th
componenttext:
Let's see. Well, the term loan -- the $550 million that was outstanding on the revolver at year-end of was repaid in early January out of proceeds of cash plus transactions that closed in January. It would be a struggle for me to actually match for you the sources and uses, but we can do that for you off-line, if you like. The term loan, which is a separate and distinct facility, which is $750 million, which was taken out for the specific purpose of matching against the capital requirements for 220 Central Park South, is in the amount of $750 million, and it had $187 million drawn at the end of the year. 
I'm advised that we have no further questions. I appreciate everybody. How many people are still left on the call?
