headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Vornado Realty Trust Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. My name is Brandon, and I'll be your operator for today. This call is being recorded for replay purposes. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to Ms.
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Vornado Realty Trust Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. My name is Brandon, and I'll be your operator for today. This call is being recorded for replay purposes. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to Ms. Cathy Creswell, Director of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Welcome to Vornado Realty Trust Second Quarter Earnings Call. Yesterday afternoon, we issued our second quarter earnings release and filed our quarterly report on Form 10-Q with the Securities and Exchange Commission. These documents as well as
componenttext:
Thank you. Welcome to Vornado Realty Trust Second Quarter Earnings Call. Yesterday afternoon, we issued our second quarter earnings release and filed our quarterly report on Form 10-Q with the Securities and Exchange Commission. These documents as well as our supplemental financial information package are available on our website, www.vno.com, under the Investor Relations section. In today's documents and during today's call, we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations of these measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures are included in our earnings release, Form 10-Q and financial supplement. Please be aware that statements made during this call may be deemed forward-looking statements, and actual results may differ materially from these statements due to a variety of risks, uncertainties and other factors. Please refer to our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission including our Form 10-K for more information regarding these risks and uncertainties. The call may include time-sensitive information that may be accurate only as of today's date. The company does not undertake a duty to update any forward-looking statements. 
On the call today from management for our opening comments are: Steven Roth, Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer; David Greenbaum, President of the New York division; Mitchell Schear, President of the Washington, D.C. division; and Stephen Theriot, Chief Financial Officer. Also in the room are: Michael Franco, Executive Vice President and Chief Investment Officer; and Joseph Macnow, Executive Vice President and Chief Administrative Officer. 
I will now turn the call over to Steven Roth.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Cathy. Good morning, everyone. Welcome to Vornado's second quarter call. Our New York business had a very strong second quarter. Business continues to be good, very good, actually, except for the hotel business, which continues to head south,
componenttext:
Thank you, Cathy. Good morning, everyone. Welcome to Vornado's second quarter call. 
Our New York business had a very strong second quarter. Business continues to be good, very good, actually, except for the hotel business, which continues to head south, our Hotel Pennsylvania included suffering from gross oversupply and a little Airbnb. We continue to participate in the bidding process for folly and Penn Station. Our vast holdings in the Penn Plaza District in the very center of the new West Side are the next big thing, actually, really big thing for our company. 
We continue down the path of separating the Washington business. Development in progress in New York continues on pace. Our 220 Central Park South residential tower is selling well and is now up to the 57th floor and rising at the rate of one floor every 4 days. Our 60,000 square foot Victoria's Secret flagship on Fifth Avenue is building towards a November opening. Construction of 61 Ninth Avenue, which will be the new home of a 20,000 square foot Starbucks Roastery is in the foundation phase. Our high land project at 512 West 22nd Street is also underway and in 606 Broadway construction has begun. 
In Washington, in Pentagon City, the Whole Foods and the 699 unit [indiscernible] have opened, achieving an extraordinary 45% leased up in just the first 2 months, way ahead of our underwriting. Down the block in Crystal City, we work, we live also open achieving 80% occupancy of the 2/3 of the units that are open. 
The success of the [indiscernible] validates our plan to emphasize residential newbuilds on our nearby vacant land inventory and on select sites created by teardowns of older office buildings in Crystal City. Over time, we will develop over 2,600 additional units in Pentagon City and over 3,000 units in Crystal City. We will put into production 577 units adjacent to the [indiscernible] immediately. 
So in Crystal City, Pentagon City, our business plan is residential heavy and newbuild heavy, while we continue to grow our office income. 
A word about the financing and transaction markets. After a period of volatility in the first quarter, the financing markets have settled down. We are in a [indiscernible] market for strong sponsors like us. The one category that has gotten tougher, however, is the construction loan market where availability has become limited and pricing has gapped out. Sponsorship is essential here. This is curtailing the supply of new condos, and speculative development in New York, which is good for us and may even create opportunities for us. 
In the transactions market after a record-breaking year in 2015, volumes are down roughly 25% year-over-year. This is driven by a variety of factors: Volatility in the first quarter, shortage of high-quality product, high prices all around and concern over fundamentals. Pricing remains strong for high-quality office and retail and multifamily product, though bidding pools have somewhat bid. Capital continues to aggressively pursue in New York, which is viewed as the safest, most vibrant and liquid market in the West and perhaps the world. We expect this to continue embedded this trend is only in the early innings. We also think Brexit will likely push additional capital to New York. 
A couple of comps that worth pointing out. 1250 Broadway, a 721,000 square foot B office building at 32nd and Broadway, a couple of blocks from our [indiscernible] and plaza holdings, went under contract to a private foreign family for $565 million, $800 per square foot, a 2.3% going in cap rate and low 5% stabilize yield. This makes us feel very good about what we own nearby as our buildings are much better located in much higher-quality.
As a retail comp, 155 [indiscernible] Street, a retail condo in SOHO occupied by Dolce and Gabbana, recently went under contract to a private investor group for $90 million at 2.6% stabilized cap rate. 
Finally, pricing at San Francisco continues to set records, 505 Howard Street, a 291,000 square foot new building near [indiscernible] center just went under contract for north of $1,200 per square foot. As the owner of the best building in San Francisco, 555 California Street, we certainly like this valuation mark. 
In May we completed a $300 million financing of 7 West 34th Street, a 477,000 square foot Manhattan office building leased to Amazon and subsequently sold a 47% ownership interest in the property to the Korea post sovereign wealth fund. The sale was based on a property value of approximately $561 million or $1,176 per square foot. We received net proceeds of $127 million from the sale and realized a net gain of $202.7 million, of which $159.5 million was recognized in the second quarter and $43.2 million has been deferred until the loan has been repaid. The [indiscernible] gain was $90 million, we continue to manage and lease the property.
Now to leasing. Company-wide, in the second quarter, we leased 1,025,000 square feet and 97 transactions. In new York, we leased 544,000 square feet of office space, including 259,000 square feet in Manhattan and 285,000 square feet in Long Island city. The average [indiscernible] rent in Manhattan was $81.67 with positive mark-to-markets of 18.2% GAAP and 11.1% cash. Starting rent for Long Island city was $40.10 with positive mark-to-markets of 34.8% GAAP and 31.4% cash. 
In Washington, we leased 369,000 square feet with mark-to-markets excluding Skyline, were flattish at negative 1.5% GAAP and 3.0% cash.
Yesterday, we called for redemption on our 6 and 7/8 Series J preferred shares in the principal amount of $246.6 million at a redemption price of par plus accrued. This will be funded out of cash balances and will result in an annual increase in FFO of $17 million or $0.08 per share. 
With that, I will now turn it over to Steve Theriot to cover our financial results and financing activities.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve. Good morning, everyone. Net income for the second quarter was $1.16 per share as compared to $0.87 per share for the second quarter of 2015. Adjusted FFO, which we formerly called comparable FFO for the second quarter was $1.23 per share
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve. Good morning, everyone. Net income for the second quarter was $1.16 per share as compared to $0.87 per share for the second quarter of 2015. Adjusted FFO, which we formerly called comparable FFO for the second quarter was $1.23 per share as compared to $1.26 per share for the second quarter of 2015. 
As we previewed on last quarter's call, this quarter -- this year's second quarter has some accounting noise, which masked the quarter's large comparable growth, so let me take you through the math. And in our New York business, the quarter's results include $7.9 million of noncash reduction of GAAP rent from the write-off of straight-line rent receivables triggered by our early termination of New York office leases, primarily J.Crew and the Structure Tone at 770 Broadway, Rocket Fuel at 100 West 33rd Street and Capital One at 90 Park Avenue, which enabled us to sign new replacement leases for these spaces with mark-to-markets of over 20% GAAP and cash. While this noncash write-off of straight-line rent receivable reduces our GAAP in earnings in 2016, the new replacement leases are accretive from an economic perspective and will benefit future for you to earnings. 
Further, when comparing this quarter's results to the prior year second quarter, remember that the prior year's second quarter included $5.4 million of noncash income from the acceleration of FAS 141 below market leases related to our early termination of the Crate & Barrel lease at 650 Madison, again, to clear out space for higher-paying tenants. 
In addition, as David will explain shortly, the Hotel Pennsylvania's results were behind last year's comparable quarter by $5.1 million. The punchline is that these items negatively affect the quarterly comparison growth of our New York core earnings by $18.4 million or $0.09 per share. Excluding these items, New York's earnings grew by $28.2 million or 11.1%. 
We reaffirm our guidance that adjusted EBITDA from our Washington business for the full year of 2016 will be $7 million to $11 million lower than 2015. 
Let me comment on our fad ratio, which exceeded 100% for the quarter and will continue to remain elevated for the balance of 2016 as capital outlays for tenant improvements and landlord's works to the bulge of leasing activity we completed in the last 2 years, is occurring ahead of the commencement of the $216.5 million of cash rental revenue from this leasing activity as described in our Form 8-K dated June 7, 2016. 
Now turning to capital markets. In the quarter, in addition to the $300 million financing of 7 West 34th Street that Steve mentioned, we completed a $273 million refinancing of the Warner Building, a 621,000 square foot Washington D.C. office building in which we have a 55% ownership interest. The loan matures in June 2023 as the fixed-rate of 3.65% is interest-only for the first 2 years and amortizes based on a 30-year schedule beginning in year 3. The property was previously encumbered by a 6.26%, $293 million mortgage. 
Also in the quarter, at 280 Park Avenue, the 1,250,000 square foot Manhattan office building we own in a joint venture, we completed a $900 million refinancing. The 3-year loan with 4, 1-year options is interest-only at LIBOR plus 2% -- 2.45% at June 30, 2016. The property was previously encumbered by a 6.35%, $725 million mortgage.
We continue to negotiate with a special servicer of the $675 million mortgage on the Skyline properties in Bailey's crossroads, Virginia. The loan is recourse only to these Skyline properties. 
In the second quarter, cash flow became insufficient to service the debt and we ceased making debt service payments. The loan is in default, causing the loan to be due and payable and subject to an incremental rate of interest. For the 3 and 6 months ended June 30, 2016, we accrued at $2.7 million of default interest expense. 
Excluding Skyline, our remaining 2016 consolidated debt maturities are $593.6 million, consisting primarily of the $550 million, 5.57% mark loan, which matures in December. This loan is in the market for refinancing as we speak. 
Our share of partially owned entities 2016 debt maturities is $75.6 million. 
Excluding Skyline and the financing of our 220 Central Park South projects, which will self liquidate as signed contracts close, our consolidated debt metrics are: Fixed-rate debt accounted for 73% of debt with a weighted average rate of 4.1% and a weighted average term of 4.6 years and a floating rate debt accounted for 27% of debt with a weighted average interest rate of 2.17% and a weighted average term of 5.2 years. Debt-to-enterprise value is 24%. Debt, net of cash to EBITDA, is 5.2x. Including our share of partially owned entities, debt other than Toys R Us, debt net of cash to EBITDA is 6.2x.
In closing, Vornado has a fortress balance sheet with modest leverage and our maturities are well staggered. We have $4.3 billion in liquidity comprised of $1.9 billion of cash, restricted cash and marketable securities and $2.4 billion undrawn under our $2.5 billion revolving credit facilities. 
I will now turn the call over to David Greenbaum.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, thank you. I want to begin my remarks this morning by offering a few observations on the current markets and what it means for Vornado. We have lived through an unusually volatile first half of this year, the China slowdown and a surprised Brexit v
componenttext:
Steve, thank you. I want to begin my remarks this morning by offering a few observations on the current markets and what it means for Vornado. We have lived through an unusually volatile first half of this year, the China slowdown and a surprised Brexit vote. Despite of the disruptive potential of these 2 events, the stock market has been resilient. While many of the headlines we have seen have described the real estate markets as "Moving sideways" the reality of what we have been seeing on the ground is that pricing of the first 6 months of the year in the city totaled 19.5 million square feet, comparable to 10-year averages, although activity was largely driven by renewals. Importantly, sublease vacancy at 1.6% is the lowest it has been in 8 years. 
On prior calls, we've talked about the important diversification of the New York marketplace with the growth of the TAMI sector making the city less reliant on a traditional financial services sector. Interestingly, this year, we have seen tremendous demand from the education sector as well as the health care sector, which has taken traditional office space for medical offices and outpatient services. Just recently, NYU Langone leased an entire building on East 41st Street. This building, which is less than 15 years old had been occupied by a prominent law firm. 
While not typically considered a large occupier of office space, over the last 5 years, some 8 million square feet has been leased by the combined health care and education sectors. And we, at Vornado, have a significant share of those operations. With Colombia University doctors at 1290 Avenue of the Americas, NYU Langone at One Park Avenue and Memorial Sloan-Kettering at 650 Madison Avenue, a total of 700,000 square feet of health care operations. 
Ultimately, the [indiscernible] market is specifically office using jobs. For the first 6 months of the year, the city added 37,000 private sector jobs to an all-time high. At 5%, the city's unemployment rate is at the lowest level since April 2007. 
Office sector jobs did reflect some weakness in May and June with a net loss of approximately 15,000 jobs, but these numbers may reflect noise attributable to Verizon strike. 2 months do not make a trend and we will continue to monitor these numbers closely.
Our portfolio is in great shape and is incredibly well-positioned. On the office side, we have 8 trophy buildings that command $100 plus rents. We have a growing concentration on Manhattan's West side, including Penn Plaza and Chelsea where tenants increasingly want to be. We have completed a string of major building redevelopments over the last 3 years totaling 6.5 million square feet ensuring that our assets remain up-to-date and attractive to tenants across all market sectors. And we now have significant additional growth opportunities associated with the redevelopments in our huge Penn Plaza portfolio. One Penn Plaza and Two Penn Plaza alone represent over 4 million square feet.
On the street retail side, our flagship portfolio is concentrated on the best high streets, Upper Fifth Avenue, the [indiscernible] Times Square, Madison Avenue, SOHO and 34th Street. 
Let me now turn to the quarter beginning with our office portfolio. Our occupancy at the end of the second quarter ticked down slightly by 40 basis points to 96%. In a
[Audio Gap]
544,000 square feet of leasing activity in 28 transactions. About 50% of our leasing activity, some 259,000 square feet was in Manhattan at starting rents of $81.67, representing mark-to-markets of 18.2% GAAP and 11.1% cash. This includes the 123,000 square foot lease with a law firm of [indiscernible] at 90 Park Avenue, which joins PWC, FactSet and Foley & Lardner as the anchor tenants in this recently redevelopments redeveloped asset. The balance of our leasing activity this quarter, some 285,000 square feet was attributable to the renewal of 2 leases with local governmental agencies at the center building in Long Island city. These leases and starting rents north of $40 per square foot reflect a rapidly changing Long Island city landscape, representing mark-to-markets of 34.8% GAAP and 31.4% cash. With these leases in place, the yield on our investment in this building is now 7% with significant additional upside still to be realized upon the releasing of the balance of this 470,000 square foot asset.
For the first 6 months of the year, we closed 6 of Craig's list of the top Manhattan office leases, a total of 775,000 square feet. PWC and Austin and Bird at 90 Park Avenue; Facebook and AOL, Verizon at 770 Broadway; Bloomberg at 731 Lexington Avenue; and Level 3 Communications at 85 Tenth Avenue. 
I spoke earlier of the quality of our New York portfolio. We continue to see that in our ability to make than our fair share of deals of $100 plus per square foot. In the second quarter, we signed 3 such leases, a total of 34,500 square feet at the average starting rents of $143 per foot. Year-to-date, we have signed 9 triple-digit leases for a total of 375,000 square feet. 
In our retail portfolio, during the second quarter, we completed 55,000 square feet of leasing activity and 10 transactions with positive mark-to-markets of 21.3% GAAP and 11.5% cash. This includes a new home for the 4 Seasons restaurant at 280 Park Avenue, which we own in joint venture. After an extensive citywide search, the 4 Seasons selected 280 Park Avenue is the perfect location to reinvent this global icon after nearly 6 decades at the [indiscernible] building. The new restaurant, when it opens in late 2017, will complement our recently completed $150 million redevelopment program, a clear sign of our success in repositioning 280 Park Avenue. 
At 692 Broadway, AOL signed a 10,000 square foot lease for a new experiential concept [indiscernible] space for the Huffington live interview series. And in 11 Penn Plaza, MSG Networks renewed some [indiscernible]  of studio space on-the-ground floor lower level. Our largest and best in class retail portfolio produced same-store results for the quarter of a positive 13.6% on a GAAP basis and 10.2% cash. 
Let me now turn to the market in Chicago. In June, we completed a $40 million renovation of the communal areas on both the ground and second floors. [indiscernible]. Our introduction of a 50-foot wide grand stair spanning over 5,000 square feet, which also serves as a 200-plus seat amphitheater for meetings and special events, a shared lounge at the top of the stairs, an outdoor green space and a giant food hall, all have received rave reviews from our tenants. And they complete the building's transition from showroom space to a crane Chicago called a top destination for top technology tenants and Chicago Tribune referred to as a magnet for companies seeking an urban millennial talent pool. And we are not done yet. Reflecting the scale of this unique asset at 3.6 million square feet and its daily population of over 25,000, as well as a transit stop directly into the building, we're now exploring opening up a retail artisan all markets featuring local specialty food offerings. I would encourage you to visit our website at vno.com and click on to the mark to see the images of this transformation or even better yet, ask Cathy Creswell to arrange a tour for you on your next visit to Chicago. 
ConAgra and [indiscernible] has now moved into the building with Suntory to follow in the fall. 
For the first 6 months of this year, we have achieved average starting rents in the building of $50.83 per square foot on 89,000 square feet of leasing activity. We are substantially full with occupancy at 97.8%. And we are continuing the transformation of this asset by converting it year end an additional 80,000 square feet of tradeshow space on the eighth floor to additional office space. The mark same-store numbers for the second quarter were a very strong positive 13% GAAP and 8.4% cash. 
Turning out to San Francisco. In the second quarter, Bank of America expanded its presence in 555 California Street to house their West Coast executive office. And just last week, after the end of the quarter, we closed a renewal lease of 50,000 square feet across 2 floors with McKinsey and Company, the renowned consulting firm, which is one of our long-standing tenants. With average starting rents north of $90 per square foot, we believe these 2 tenants on top of the best tenant roster in town, reaffirmed the building's status as the premier office building in San Francisco. But we don't take that status for granted and we have kicked off the redevelopment program and redesign of the concourse level amenities in the 1.8 million square foot 555 California complex. This will include upgrade [indiscernible] amenity spaces and, of course, multiple new food offerings. 
The occupancy in the complex now stands at 92.1%, reflecting the space that we recently got back when BOA vacated its original banking queue. We're now working on plans for an adaptive reuse for what we call the queue and are in active dialogue with tenants seeking an iconic presence as part of the streetscape of San Francisco.
Overall for the New York division, we had a very strong quarter with same-store increases of 6.9% GAAP, 2.9% [ph] cash. These same-store numbers include the results of the Hotel Pennsylvania Whereas Steve mentioned, business has been very weak, reflecting a day down cycle in the New York tell business. If you exclude the Hotel Pennsylvania our same-store number for the second quarter were a robust positive 9.2% GAAP and 8.5% cash.
To conclude my remarks, let me say, we remain very constructive on the New York marketplace. With a highly diversified multi-tenant portfolio, lease expirations are quite modest for the balance of this year at 350,000 square feet and modest next year as we look out with 800,000 square feet of expiries with no one tenant representing more than 120,000 square feet. All of these reflects our aggressive leasing program where over the last 2.5 years, we have leased 7.5 million square feet. And our pipeline of activity remains strong with over 1 million square feet of leases in active dialogue.
Thank you. I'll now turn the call over to Mitchell Schear to cover Washington.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David, and good morning, everybody. I'll begin with a few comments on the D.C. market. The Washington D.C. metropolitan area economy is continuing its positive direction. Nearly 72,000 jobs were added in the 12 months ending April 2016. Importa
componenttext:
Thank you, David, and good morning, everybody. I'll begin with a few comments on the D.C. market. The Washington D.C. metropolitan area economy is continuing its positive direction. Nearly 72,000 jobs were added in the 12 months ending April 2016. Importantly, for our business, 24% of that growth is being driven by office using professional and business services, including tech-related and stem sectors. 
Unemployment in the D.C. region have continued downward, is now at a very low 3.5% for the region as compared to 4.7% for the country. In the second quarter, both Downtown D.C. and Northern Virginia absorption picked up with 370,000 square feet in Northern Virginia and 526,000 square feet in D.C.  Year-to-date, the numbers are showing slow, but steady absorption. 
In residential, the D.C. metro area is experiencing modest positive absorption. Notwithstanding the positive economic backdrop, the real estate market continues to bounce along the bottom. 
Let me review our second quarter leasing in occupancy metric and please note all of these exclude Skyline property. We completed a 326,000 square feet of office and retail leases in 39 transactions. Mark-to-markets were flattish, negative 1.5% GAAP and negative 3% cash. Overall occupancy was 91.3%, down 80 basis points from 92.1% in the first quarter. 
Office occupancy decreased to 89.2% from 90.6% in the first quarter. The primary driver of the lower occupancy is 2 GSA tenants who vacated, both of which we expected. We are seeing activity from smaller tenants, 5,000 to 20,000 square feet. 
And finally, residential occupancy increased by 120 basis points to 98.2%. 
In our Crystal City and Pentagon City residential business, it was a very active quarter. In June, we opened the Bartlett [ph], our new 699 unit apartment building in Pentagon City. Located directly a top Whole Foods, this 23-story building has unbeatable views of the Washington Skyline and the best residential amenity package in the metropolitan D.C. area. When surveyed, 67% of our residents reported that they selected the Bartlett due to our extensive amenity package, consisting of 40,000 square feet of indoor and outdoor space, validating our intense focus on the tenant experience.
The market responds to the Bartlett thus far has been terrific. Our first renter's moved in on June 2 and through yesterday, we have leased 314 units, that's 45% of the building already. With this philosophy and rents that are higher than we projected, we are very pleased with our performance to-date. 
Meanwhile, in Crystal City, we [indiscernible] first location in Northern Virginia in our building at 2221 South Clark Street. Here, we transformed an older office building into WeWork community that combines 216 community style apartments with their proven co-working office space. This collaborative living approach has attracted a whole new crowd to the streets of Crystal City and is invigorating. The leasing activity has been strong with 80% of the units occupied that have opened to-date. We are pleased to be WeWork's partner in this mentor.
The Bartlett and WeLive brings our residential portfolio to over 3,300 units. Our properties are all metro served in Georgetown and [indiscernible] Arlington. We like this business in these locations and plan to continue our expansion. As Steve mentioned, in July, we received approvals to develop the next phase of the metropolitan park block, a new 577 unit apartment project right next to The Bartlett. The building will feature [indiscernible]  style architecture coupled with Vornado signature premium amenities and 10,000 square feet of additional retail. It will stand 22 stories tall and like The Bartlett, will have commanding views of D.C. We plan to start construction at the beginning of next year.
Including this new project, we can build almost 5,600 additional apartment in Crystal City and Pentagon City on vacant land that we already own and on a few sites created by a few select tear downs of aging office buildings. 
In Downtown D.C, at the corner of 17th and M streets, we are emptying the final tenant to make way for our new 335,000 square foot trophy office building, 1700M Street. Our plan is to begin demolition within the next 90 days and build a new garage and foundation back to grade while actively marketing the building. With the garage and foundation complete, this will put us in an excellent position competitively to go vertical when the time is right. 
I thank you and I will now turn the call over to the operator for Q&A.

componenttext: It's Michael Bilerman with Manny. Steve in your opening remarks, you said that you continue down the path of separation for the D.C. business. I'm wondering if you can expand on that a little bit. How much of that is solely spinning off of business as is versus potentially exploring other structures in terms of sale, joint ventures, mergers, I guess is it a spin or go? Or is there others things still being discussed?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, I don't think that I have a very much more to say than I had said. We're continuing down the path. We have not been bashful in saying over the last number of quarters that we thought that this was a very -- a good idea for both businesses, and we
componenttext: Michael, I don't think that I have a very much more to say than I had said. We're continuing down the path. We have not been bashful in saying over the last number of quarters that we thought that this was a very -- a good idea for both businesses, and we've said frequently, publicly the reasons why we think that's true. All that continues and we continue down that path. With respect to the other part of your question about conversations that we might or might having with other people, et cetera, I don't think I have anything more to say about that.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then my follow up is just in terms of balance sheet management. You called the preferreds or at least one of the series of preferreds. I guess, what's your view on the remaining, you still have another $1 billion of this stuff outstanding, call it, ar
componenttext: And then my follow up is just in terms of balance sheet management. You called the preferreds or at least one of the series of preferreds. I guess, what's your view on the remaining, you still have another $1 billion of this stuff outstanding, call it, around a 6% yield. Do you think about the return you're getting on almost $2 billion of cash pretty much nothing versus the cost of debt today, whether it be 10-year, even 30-year debt, I guess, why not take out the whole stack of preferreds and I can remember 15, 20 years ago, you used to click that preferreds at the maturity date of never but it just seems like a pretty high cost to be paying for that money or there's alternative today. So maybe just talk about the remaining preferreds and your thought on cap structure?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I like your memory with due date of never, I remember that, by the way, that's still true. I mean, your comments are valid. We have always for as long as I run this company, which is decades, had a slug of $1 billion plus of preferred, which has a due dat
componenttext: I like your memory with due date of never, I remember that, by the way, that's still true. I mean, your comments are valid. We have always for as long as I run this company, which is decades, had a slug of $1 billion plus of preferred, which has a due date of never and the reason for that was it creates stability and it creates -- it's better than debt and better than common stock. Now today, we're in a period where and by the way, the other thing about this perpetual preferred is that it's asymmetrical in its call arrangements because the issuer can call after 5 years without penalty, which is we think asymmetrical feature in our favor. So we have called the first one. We will pay for it out of cash balances. That will increase our distributable earnings by $70 million and we think that's fine. We have reviewed the balance of that portfolio -- of that preferred stack and obviously, we're thinking about our options. Our options are do nothing; leave those various series in place; pay them off, which would then change the complexion of our liquidity a little bit or maybe even more than a little bit; or refinance them at lower rates as perpetual preferred. My guess is that the current rate for Vornado's credit in that market is about 5.25%, maybe even a pinch below that. So those are the options, we're considering them, but we have nothing to say about that at the current time.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: From Bank of America, we have Jamie Feldman online.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you had commented also Penn Plaza and Moynihan Station being big part of the company's future. Can you just give us an update on where you stand today in terms of maybe the bid from Moynihan and update on lands and timing and spending?
componenttext: So you had commented also Penn Plaza and Moynihan Station being big part of the company's future. Can you just give us an update on where you stand today in terms of maybe the bid from Moynihan and update on lands and timing and spending?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jamie, the answer is, obviously, the Penn Plaza District is, I've said this before, kind of -- is the big kahuna, we have vast holdings there. And interestingly, as the island of Manhattan tilts to the west and tilts to the south, we find ourselves in the
componenttext: Jamie, the answer is, obviously, the Penn Plaza District is, I've said this before, kind of -- is the big kahuna, we have vast holdings there. And interestingly, as the island of Manhattan tilts to the west and tilts to the south, we find ourselves in the bull's-eye of the new West side of Manhattan with great opportunity. So if you just look at our office buildings there with the current in-place rent versus what they rent might be in the future, we have a very, very, very good economic situation. With respect to the bidding process of Moynihan and Farley and Penn Station, this is a government procurement process, which is being run very carefully by the government, and we really cannot and do not have anything to say about that process other than we are an aggressive participant. With respect to the timing of that, we can't predict it. And with respect to the capital that will be required to transform Penn Plaza, we are aggressively anxious to get underway as quickly as we can. We have the capital, we have the plans and we have the property, most importantly, we have the property. So I think that, that pretty much covers it. Whatever happens in that district with respect to the bidding process, the district is transformed forever by the tilt toward the west side of Manhattan that's going on in the marketplace.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then a follow-up you mentioned on 2017, there's no lease expiring more than I think 125,000 square feet. Can you maybe dovetail that with your latest, the NOI bridge, I think the $200 million of New York NOI that's a little since your and my pre
componenttext: Okay. And then a follow-up you mentioned on 2017, there's no lease expiring more than I think 125,000 square feet. Can you maybe dovetail that with your latest, the NOI bridge, I think the $200 million of New York NOI that's a little since your and my presentation based on leasing in the second quarter? Maybe just tell us where that stands and how to think about expirations for next year?

componenttext: David, you want to handle that one?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: The NOI bridge, Jamie, which we talked about on our last call, realistically, was attributable to the bulge of leasing activity that we had completed over the last couple of years, which I talked about, the 7.5 million square feet, including the activity
componenttext: The NOI bridge, Jamie, which we talked about on our last call, realistically, was attributable to the bulge of leasing activity that we had completed over the last couple of years, which I talked about, the 7.5 million square feet, including the activity realistically in the first quarter, the PWC lease and as well as the Alston & Bird lease, we just signed was actually 2018 expiration, which we forward leased. So as I look out in terms of basically the, call it, 4% vacancy that we have in the portfolio and a relatively modest amount of expirations that we have coming up for the balance of this year and into next, we've got, call it, 1.1 million square feet, 1.2 million square feet of lease expiring coming up over the next 18 months. We are in dialogue right now with probably about half of that space in terms of tenant renewals. And similarly, in terms of vacant space or space that we expect to get back, for example, we know in the second half of this year, we're going to be getting back space from U.S. Customs, which is a tenant that moved into our building after the catastrophe of 9/11 and is moving back into World Trade Center Downtown, we've got very good activity. So I don't think Steve, unless we want to say anything specifically about the bridge, I don't think there's anything material to talk about in terms of that number?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. I would just add a couple of things, Jamie. The huge, what we call, bulge of leasing, 7.5 million square feet that we did over the last couple of years has accomplished several things. Number one, it basically ensured the income of the company
componenttext: Yes, sure. I would just add a couple of things, Jamie. The huge, what we call, bulge of leasing, 7.5 million square feet that we did over the last couple of years has accomplished several things. Number one, it basically ensured the income of the company for years in the future. Second, the leasing was done at higher rents, which ensures a really huge growth. I mean, we mentioned that in an 8-K, I think, a couple of months ago, which is I think is $216 million, something like that number. And so we ensure the bulge of leasing we accomplished over the last couple of years ensures the income and the rising income in the future of the company for years to come.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Jamie just to follow up on the bridge that we did in that June 7, 8-K and we used up the meeting, when we remeasured our forecast data as of the end of Q2, we were on track with the information that we had presented previously. And so it's moving acco
componenttext: And Jamie just to follow up on the bridge that we did in that June 7, 8-K and we used up the meeting, when we remeasured our forecast data as of the end of Q2, we were on track with the information that we had presented previously. And so it's moving according to what we would've expected, which isn't surprising given that it's all contractual.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: From Sandler O'Neill, we have Alexander Goldfarb online.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, just on the D.C. decision, one of the things you guys had outlined was that D.C. and New York had divergent and different return thresholds and therefore, would be difficult for D.C. to get out of funding relative to the potential New York investme
componenttext: Steve, just on the D.C. decision, one of the things you guys had outlined was that D.C. and New York had divergent and different return thresholds and therefore, would be difficult for D.C. to get out of funding relative to the potential New York investment. So if the decision is made to not go forward with D.C. and yet D.C. have a lot more resi, a lot more development in it, how do we reconcile that sort of concept that D.C. would need more capital and yet, the return seemed to be better in New York?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alex, I don't -- I sort of challenge your basic assumption. The capital that is going to be invested in D.C. will be invested for fine profits and find returns. So I'll give you an example. I mean, we're thrilled with Bartlett. If you all haven't seen it
componenttext: Alex, I don't -- I sort of challenge your basic assumption. The capital that is going to be invested in D.C. will be invested for fine profits and find returns. So I'll give you an example. I mean, we're thrilled with Bartlett. If you all haven't seen it all trip down there and take a look. It's the largest scale apartment building, the largest amenity package and the most well-received, I think, than in the Washington district in years, in years, in years. From a math point of view, we created that building at a, give or take, a 7 and the value of that building, if you value the marketplace for first class apartment and brand new product, is x. If you divide those 2 numbers, there is a very satisfactory return on that capital. By the way, we built that building free and clear. We didn't use any debt to use that building. So the long and short of it is, and I think I said in my prepared remarks that we want to get as many of those Bartlett buildings, we want to build the next one immediately, the one after that quickly and more an d more and more. So we think that that's a very interesting business. Now we -- and we're excited about it. So we have the ingredients to make that happen. Most importantly, we have the very scarce, very important land of holdings in and around the Pentagon City and in Crystal City, so if you don't have the land, you're not going anywhere. The second thing is we have the capital to do this development. Third is the return expectations are actually terrific, very satisfactory. And we have the management team that has proven the ability to develop these assets. So we are extremely optimistic about the development in and around Crystal City and Pentagon City. And I don't think I was bashful in my opening remarks. Now I look at this all differently. If we do separate and by the way, we have sort of, that's the path that we're going on. So if we do complete that, I have full intention of holding my shares in Vornado and holding my shares in Washington, call it, whatever you want to call it. So I look upon it is if just moving from one pocket to the other. It well-capitalized with enough capital, I'm talking about Washington-co or the spin-co, to complete its development and complete its mission and there you have it. So I don't think it's an either/or. I think that our company will do both if we separate the businesses, the new business will be capitalized to complete its development initiative for sure.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, it's helpful, Steve. On the second question is, just on a project specific basis, 606 Broadway, 3,000 a foot for office retail combo, can you give us a little bit more color as far as maybe rent expectations? Or what's driving -- I mean, the land co
componenttext: Okay, it's helpful, Steve. On the second question is, just on a project specific basis, 606 Broadway, 3,000 a foot for office retail combo, can you give us a little bit more color as far as maybe rent expectations? Or what's driving -- I mean, the land cost that was high but what's driving it doubly, it's a desirable purchase for what you guys spent, but clearly there's a -- it's not your typical office retail development?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that's true. First of all, we love the spot. We love the exposure. It's like -- it's kind of a Hollywood front, it's all front and very little depth. So it's an extremely visible -- it's an extremely, extremely visible asset and a very important par
componenttext: Well, that's true. First of all, we love the spot. We love the exposure. It's like -- it's kind of a Hollywood front, it's all front and very little depth. So it's an extremely visible -- it's an extremely, extremely visible asset and a very important part of Manhattan. So there's that. It's absolutely small. The knock on this deal is why internally when we talk about it, it's small, small for us. But nonetheless, we thought that the asset was of such quality that we wanted to take a shot, and we did. So it's expensive per square foot. We are optimistic that the rents will justify and by the way, at the lower end of return thresholds. This is not going to be a for beggar [ph]. But we like the promise of the asset. It's small, which is negative. We think it will generate rents that will justify the high cost And we just can't predict the rents now, it's too early, we're just getting started.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: But you would think sort of mid-single digits or higher than that?
componenttext: But you would think sort of mid-single digits or higher than that?

componenttextpreview: It'll be in the -- it'll be higher than mid, but certainly not double digits.
componenttext: It'll be in the -- it'll be higher than mid, but certainly not double digits.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: From Evercore ISI, we have Steve Sakwa.
componenttext: From Evercore ISI, we have Steve Sakwa.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, you mentioned -- you talked about some of the pricing comps whether be it in New York or in San Francisco, and I'm just curious, how you're sort of thinking about kind of acquisitions and dispositions in this point in the cycle and whether you and
componenttext: Steve, you mentioned -- you talked about some of the pricing comps whether be it in New York or in San Francisco, and I'm just curious, how you're sort of thinking about kind of acquisitions and dispositions in this point in the cycle and whether you and you more capital, make special dividends to shareholders or just kind of stay tad as it is right now?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a huge omnibus question. Let me see if I can tackle it in pieces. First off, we're very, very happy with where we are -- where we stand right now. We worked very hard for the last 3, 4 years to get here. So our debt is very low. When Steve Theriot
componenttext: That's a huge omnibus question. Let me see if I can tackle it in pieces. First off, we're very, very happy with where we are -- where we stand right now. We worked very hard for the last 3, 4 years to get here. So our debt is very low. When Steve Theriot went through some of statistics, he just said casually, well,l our debt is 25%. Well 25% is extraordinarily low. Our debt ratios are great. Our liquidity is superb, the best in the business. And so we're very pleased with that position. Having said that, we -- evidenced by our calling a series of preferreds yesterday that the leasing that it's not inappropriate to pay off high 6% securities with cash that's earning nil, which will augment and increase our earnings. It doesn't affect us from an NAV point of view but it certainly increases our earnings. In terms of acquisitions and dispositions, I said over the last better part of the year and a half, maybe even longer that pricing in the marketplace is high, that the easy money has been made and that we look upon acquisitions with great care and scrutiny. And that continues to be the case. There has been no decline in pricing for first quality assets that we seek. There has been some disruption in the hotel market, there hasn't been a hotel sold in Manhattan this year to-date and the reason is that hotel business as we've discussed already is very soft. Obviously, the condo -- well, not obviously, but factually, the condo market is also soft, or not our condo, of course, but other people's condos, that's sort of a joke. But it's really not a joke, it's really factual. And so we are not aggressively interested in buying at the prices that are currently -- that first-class properties are currently offered. And so I think that's where we are. Now these markets are volatile, they can change. We are ready for whatever happens. And I think there you have that, my friend.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I don't know if you or David would appear to do it just a way, maybe recap on retail that's obviously, lots of than certain kind of in the marketplaces is over the street retail business in general and of where rents are in some of the softness
componenttext: Okay. And I don't know if you or David would appear to do it just a way, maybe recap on retail that's obviously, lots of than certain kind of in the marketplaces is over the street retail business in general and of where rents are in some of the softness that we're seeing on lower part of Fifth, but maybe just a quick nutshell, can you kind around Manhattan and sort of tell us how things are today?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. As I've said for way more than 1 year now, rents in Manhattan has gotten too high. So our job is to be realistic. We're not in the hope business, we're in the real estate business. And so we believe rents have gotten to a point where they are too hi
componenttext: Sure. As I've said for way more than 1 year now, rents in Manhattan has gotten too high. So our job is to be realistic. We're not in the hope business, we're in the real estate business. And so we believe rents have gotten to a point where they are too high and retailers are not comfortable paying those rents. So that's step one. The second part of it is our retail portfolio is pretty full, very full, actually. We completed the last 2 big deals in town, the Victoria's Secret, huge make a deal on Fifth Avenue and the Swatch megadeal on Upper Fifth as well. So we're very pleased with our positioning. The quality of our assets is the best in town by far. Now let's go around the horn. The liquidity or the depth of the retail market has gotten very thin. So 4 years ago or 5 years ago, there might have been 3 or 4 or more retailers bidding for a particular crime space on a prime street. Right now, there's barely 1 or 2. And it's difficult to close because people -- retailers are concerned, retailers are concerned about their own business models and less concerned about expansion. So the market is slow, retail rents or asking rents are too high, we're aware of that and obviously, we're in the business of being realistic and making deals. And I think the soft markets are where the volumes on the street are not doing well. So Madison Avenue is soft. Lower Fifth is very soft. Upper Fifth is, the volumes are fine, but the number of tenants that want to pay the rents are scarce. Times Square continues to be, I believe, the strongest, in my opinion, the strongest market in the city. SoHo and Broadway are softish. 34th Street is doing fine. So I think that's going around the horn.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: From Stifel, we have John Guinee.
componenttext: From Stifel, we have John Guinee.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions. One, I guess, for Mitchell, you mentioned something sort of interesting about tearing down Crystal City buildings, you've got 21 buildings there, about 7 million square feet. Which ones, or can you give us a general sense as to what would b
componenttext: Two questions. One, I guess, for Mitchell, you mentioned something sort of interesting about tearing down Crystal City buildings, you've got 21 buildings there, about 7 million square feet. Which ones, or can you give us a general sense as to what would be torn down and why? And then the next question is big picture, Steve, Steve, et cetera, you guys have done a fabulous job of trying to help the Street understand future economics, 7% return on The Bartlett, $216 million NOI bridge. I think for most on a lot of people's mind is how they actually quantify what's going on at Penn Station? When would you be in a position to do that? And what magnitude are we talking about in terms of total dollars committed?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a mouthful. Mitchell, do you want to handle the teardowns at Crystal City for a second and, I'll counter punch and then we'll get into the rest of John's question.
componenttext: That's a mouthful. Mitchell, do you want to handle the teardowns at Crystal City for a second and, I'll counter punch and then we'll get into the rest of John's question.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, John. In Crystal City, there really, if we just focus on 2 particular assets, we have a vacant asset on Crystal drive with what we used to refer to as Mall 3 and we also have a building plaza 5 on 23rd Street. Those are -- those buildings aggregate
componenttext: Sure, John. In Crystal City, there really, if we just focus on 2 particular assets, we have a vacant asset on Crystal drive with what we used to refer to as Mall 3 and we also have a building plaza 5 on 23rd Street. Those are -- those buildings aggregate about 0.5 million square feet. Those buildings are currently, basically empty and ready for redevelopment. So if you take those buildings and look at what we can build as a result of the Crystal City sector plan, we have almost 2 million square feet on that 500,000 plus square feet of what's built at the moment and each of those sites could handle ultimately up to 1,000 apartment units. So I think, we think, that it is -- it makes all good economic sense. It makes all good sense with respect to place making and adding these apartments and in terms of what the overall mix would be.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me give you a little bit more on that same topic. So what we're going to do is take the oldest, most -- the oldest building, so the oldest buildings are 40 years old, something like that, office buildings. And we have worked with the government powers
componenttext: Let me give you a little bit more on that same topic. So what we're going to do is take the oldest, most -- the oldest building, so the oldest buildings are 40 years old, something like that, office buildings. And we have worked with the government powers that be so that in general, we can take down an older building and we build a building, which is 150% the size of that or something like that, okay? So the financial analysis goes like this. You take this 40-year old building or whatever and throw a significant amount of capital into that building to lid it with the understanding that, that capital will have to be amortized over, pick a number, a 10-year lease and at the end of that 10-year lease, that 40 year-old building is now 50 years old, so that's one column of numbers and concept. The second column is you take it down, build a brand-new residential building which will have, which in today's environment has the lowest exiting cap rate or value rate and that's just a matter of math. And we believe that the math shows that the teardown of the oldest buildings in favor of brand-new first-class residential product is a very, very profitable and good trade. In addition to that, the -- when you get thousands of units in a tight cluster you get a community and that creates more value and we know how to create that community and amenitize it and make it so that people will consider this a very, very fine place to live thinking about where it is, where it's located, where jobs are, the metro access of it and by the way, it is a very short walk to Pentagon City Mall, which is 1 of the top 10 malls in the country and the Whole Foods, et cetera. So we believe that there is a -- we believe in the future of Crystal City, Pentagon City and these assets. We believe in it greatly. Now having said all that, I forgot the second question.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just the magnitude of what you're doing at Penn Station is just stunning, 4 million square feet at 1 and 2 Penn, probably teardown Hotel Pennsylvania, the skirt, all sort of ancillary assets that you own there that [indiscernible] and everything else. Is
componenttext: Just the magnitude of what you're doing at Penn Station is just stunning, 4 million square feet at 1 and 2 Penn, probably teardown Hotel Pennsylvania, the skirt, all sort of ancillary assets that you own there that [indiscernible] and everything else. Is this $2 million -- or $2 billion or $20 billion in capital committed over how many years with what sort of return on cost?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so listen John, as excited as I am about what I just said about Pentagon City and Crystal City, I'm even more excited about Penn Station, okay? So really, when you think about it, you have to take into bite-size pieces, okay? First is that the change
componenttext: Yes, so listen John, as excited as I am about what I just said about Pentagon City and Crystal City, I'm even more excited about Penn Station, okay? So really, when you think about it, you have to take into bite-size pieces, okay? First is that the change in the submarket and the reorientation of the market's preferences for geography in Manhattan, so we think we've got the bull's-eye, okay? So we've got $1 billion Macy's and Madison Square Garden and we sit on top of the Station. We don't sit 4 blocks away and you have to walk to it in the rain, we sit on top of it. So the basic and by the way, and the basis that we have in our building says go back in history when we started putting together the assemblage 15 years ago, our basis is pretty extraordinary. So you have all that as a backdrop. Now the way we look at it, let's take and cut it into bite-size pieces. So take 1 Penn and to ban, which together are 4 million plus square feet. The average rents are published you know where they are, they, the first digit is a 5 and we believe that notwithstanding anything else, we can transform those buildings in this marketplace so that the average starting rent will be higher, [indiscernible] to math now but higher than what they are now maybe even quite substantially higher. So that's a capital program, and we're going to do that and that's actually the #1 priority of what we're about. And then there's development, the retail opportunities are unique and extraordinary. And then we've got some big stuff like the Hotel Penn, which we have, I think, very intelligently delayed up until now. And so you have it. We do is we take -- we leg into the project piece-by-piece. Now with respect to the overall amount of capital that we will be committing to this district, district it's 8 million, 9 million feet, it's huge, it's enormous, it all has very large paybacks and the most important part of it is Vornado is a fortress, financially, and has the capital ability to finance all this. So I'm not ready to put out any numbers. I'm only able to right now to talk about the concept and I can't tell you how excited we are about this opportunity, and we're pretty excited about Crystal City and Pentagon City, too.

componenttext: They progressed to signature. So 220 Central Park South is a very public project. The residential market, so everything that I say gets into the newspapers and whatever. So we don't really have a lot to say about 220 South Central Park other than that, a, it's selling fabulously well. There's never been a project in New York that has sold as well. There was a slowdown in the marketplace for 5 or 6 months. That slowed down, and in a couple of months ago we're getting good traffic. The traffic that we're getting are extremely qualified buyers. The project is heavily skewed towards New Yorkers and Americans and we couldn't be more delighted. The project is exceeding our expectations, both in terms of sales velocity and numerical performance.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jed, so I think that if you look at what's happening with the Bartlett, we said that in a very short period of time, we've leased 45% of the building. So we think that a heavy amenitized building, you give somebody a really efficient, plus or minus 700 sq
componenttext: Jed, so I think that if you look at what's happening with the Bartlett, we said that in a very short period of time, we've leased 45% of the building. So we think that a heavy amenitized building, you give somebody a really efficient, plus or minus 700 square foot, one bedroom apartment and you give them a tremendous amount of amenities in the building, we think that's a real formula for success and there's real market demand for that. Having said that, in the Pentagon, Crystal City market, we really control a substantial amount of the development pipeline. There are some other projects, there are some other units, but not a significant amount over the pipeline period that we're thinking about. So we have the opportunity to both build a quality product, measure the demand, meet the demand and also modulate the supply as we see it. So we're very comfortable with our position and with our program at this point.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jed, I'm going to be a little bit more aggressive in answering. So at 220 South Central Park, you seem to be especially interested in, we have the best site, we have the best project, we have the best design, et cetera, but as importantly, we bring a 2% c
componenttext: Jed, I'm going to be a little bit more aggressive in answering. So at 220 South Central Park, you seem to be especially interested in, we have the best site, we have the best project, we have the best design, et cetera, but as importantly, we bring a 2% cost of capital to that project. We are competing against people up and down the block, in fact, all over the place, that are paying 12% and 15% for money as you can imagine, it's not a fair fight, okay? In Crystal City and Pentagon City, my thinking is not dissimilar to that. We own great land parcels and so I look upon that right now as being a sub-cost. We have the capital to build and develop and this is different than office buildings. If you put up 300,000 to 400,000, 500,000 office building and you catch a weak market, the building either stays a vacant for year-after-year for by your by the way there's dozen of example of that in the Washington region or you have to take the price down to a number, which locks in a huge loss. Residential development is different than fact and that is if of a very marginal reduction in the monthly rate, you can get to -- you can rent and you can get absorption. So it's a totally different business. Now the other thing that's interesting is that in the office side, you sign a long-term lease and you're locked in to that price, good or bad, for a very long time. In the residential business, the rents, will fluctuate with the market and so over time, you're able to get what the market is the market think is that a fair rent. So they're very different. We will be aggressive in building on the land that we already own there, that's our business plan.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have the full array of skill sets in here. We have a monster fortress balance sheet for capital, we have the best operating platform in the business, we have the best leasing teams in the business, we have the best construction and development teams in
componenttext: We have the full array of skill sets in here. We have a monster fortress balance sheet for capital, we have the best operating platform in the business, we have the best leasing teams in the business, we have the best construction and development teams in the business. So we have the full array of skills and strengths needed to function in good markets and in bad markets. We run our business and have run it for decades so that we are strongest when the market gets weakest because that's the time when -- that's the best time to invest. Having said that, I mean, it's pretty obvious what our preferences are. Our preferences are to be an equity player as opposed to a lender. Our preferences are to be an income-producing property business as opposed to a onetime for sale condo business. We're doing 220 Central Park now, the last one was a dozen years ago on top of the Bloomberg, so this is not a regular business for us. And the -- so our preference is to be an owner rather than a lender. Our preference is to be an equity holder rather than a seller. The product types that we are expert in are obviously office and retail. So those are the 2 -- that's where our 2 main interests are. We also have a residential portfolio in Manhattan, which is performing quite well and that is a business with the correct entry point that we would invest in. Although we do not any where near the scale in that business that we have in office and it retail. So having said that, we're open for business every day. And we have a history over the years of making some of our very best deals when there's some level of distress or disruption in the lending market, people get overleveraged, et cetera, so we are very alert and looking toward that as we speak.
