headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Michael Bilerman with Manny. Steve, in your opening remarks, you said that you continue down the path of separation for the D.C. business. I'm wondering if you can expand on that a little bit. How much of that is solely spinning off the business as i
componenttext: It's Michael Bilerman with Manny. Steve, in your opening remarks, you said that you continue down the path of separation for the D.C. business. I'm wondering if you can expand on that a little bit. How much of that is solely spinning off the business as is versus potentially exploring other structures in terms of sale, joint ventures, mergers, I guess is it a spin or go? Or is other things still being discussed?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think that I have a very much more to say than I have said. We're continuing down the path. We have not been bashful in saying over the last number of quarters that we thought that this was a very -- a good idea for both businesses, and we've said
componenttext: I don't think that I have a very much more to say than I have said. We're continuing down the path. We have not been bashful in saying over the last number of quarters that we thought that this was a very -- a good idea for both businesses, and we've said frequently publicly the reasons why we think that's true. All that continues and we continue down that path. With respect to the other part of your question about conversations that we might or might not be having with other people, et cetera, I don't think I have anything more to say about that.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then my follow up is just in terms of balance sheet management. You called the preferreds or at least one of the series of preferreds. I guess, what's your view on the remaining, you still have another $1 billion of this stuff outstanding, call it, ar
componenttext: And then my follow up is just in terms of balance sheet management. You called the preferreds or at least one of the series of preferreds. I guess, what's your view on the remaining, you still have another $1 billion of this stuff outstanding, call it, around a 6% yield. Do you think about the return you're getting on almost $2 billion of cash pretty much nothing versus the cost of debt today, whether it be 10-year, even 30-year debt, I guess, why not take out the whole stack of preferreds and I can remember 15, 20 years ago, you used to click that preferreds at the maturity date of never but it just seems like a pretty high cost to be paying for that money where there's alternatives today. So maybe just talk about the remaining preferreds and your thoughts on cap structure?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I like your memory with a due date of never, I remember that, by the way, that's still true. I mean, I think your comments are valid. We have always for as long as I've run this company, which is decades, had a slug of $1 billion plus of preferred, which
componenttext: I like your memory with a due date of never, I remember that, by the way, that's still true. I mean, I think your comments are valid. We have always for as long as I've run this company, which is decades, had a slug of $1 billion plus of preferred, which has a due date of never and the reason for that was it creates stability and it creates -- it's better than debt and better than common stock. Now today, we're in a period where --and by the way, the other thing about this perpetual preferred is that it's asymmetrical in its call arrangements because the issuer can call after 5 years without penalty, which is we think as asymmetrical feature in our favor. So we have called the first one. We will pay for it out of cash balances. That will increase our distributable earnings by $17 million and we think that's fine. We have reviewed the balance of that portfolio -- of that preferred stack and obviously, we're thinking about our options. Our options are do nothing; leave those various series in place; pay them off, which would then change the complexion of our liquidity a little bit or maybe even more than a little bit; or refinance them at lower rates as perpetual preferred. My guess is that the current rate for Vornado's credit in that market is about 5.25%, maybe even a pinch below that. So those are the options, we're considering them, but we have nothing to say about that at the current time.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: From Bank of America, we have Jamie Feldman online.
componenttext: From Bank of America, we have Jamie Feldman online.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you had commented also Penn Plaza and Moynihan Station being big part of the company's future. Can you just give us an update on where you stand today in terms of maybe the bid from Moynihan and just an update on plans and timing and spending?
componenttext: So you had commented also Penn Plaza and Moynihan Station being big part of the company's future. Can you just give us an update on where you stand today in terms of maybe the bid from Moynihan and just an update on plans and timing and spending?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jamie, the answer is, obviously, the Penn Plaza District is, I've said this before, kind of -- is the big kahuna. We have vast holdings there. And interestingly, as the island of Manhattan tilts to the West and tilts to the South, we find ourselves in the
componenttext: Jamie, the answer is, obviously, the Penn Plaza District is, I've said this before, kind of -- is the big kahuna. We have vast holdings there. And interestingly, as the island of Manhattan tilts to the West and tilts to the South, we find ourselves in the bull's-eye of the new West side of Manhattan with great opportunity. So if you just looked at our office buildings there with the current in-place rent versus what the rents might be in the future, we have a very, very, very good economic situation. With respect to the bidding process of Moynihan and Farley and Penn Station, this is a government procurement process which is being run very carefully by the government, and we really cannot and do not have anything to say about that process other than we are an aggressive participant. With respect to the timing of that, we can't predict it. And with respect to the capital that will be required to transform Penn Plaza, we are aggressively anxious to get underway as quickly as we can. We have the capital, we have the plans and we have the property -- most importantly, we have the property. So I think that, that pretty much covers it. Whatever happens in that district with respect to the bidding process, the district is transformed forever by the tilt toward the West side of Manhattan that's going on in the marketplace.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then a follow-up -- and then just a follow-up on -- you mentioned on 2017, there's no lease expiring more than, I think, 125,000 square feet. Can you maybe dovetail that with your latest, the NOI bridge -- I think the $200 million of New York NO
componenttext: Okay. And then a follow-up -- and then just a follow-up on -- you mentioned on 2017, there's no lease expiring more than, I think, 125,000 square feet. Can you maybe dovetail that with your latest, the NOI bridge -- I think the $200 million of New York NOI, I assume that's moved a little since your NAV presentation based on leasing in the second quarter? Maybe just tell us where that stands and how to think about expirations for next year?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, you want to handle that one?
componenttext: David, you want to handle that one?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: The NOI bridge, Jamie, which we talked about on our last call, realistically, was attributable to the bulge of leasing activity that we had completed over the last couple of years, which I talked about, the 7.5 million square feet, including the activity
componenttext: The NOI bridge, Jamie, which we talked about on our last call, realistically, was attributable to the bulge of leasing activity that we had completed over the last couple of years, which I talked about, the 7.5 million square feet, including the activity realistically, in the first quarter, the PWC lease and as well as the Alston & Bird lease, which we just signed, was actually 2018 expiration, which we forward leased. So as I look out in terms of basically the, call it, 4% vacancy that we have in the portfolio and a relatively modest amount of expirations that we have coming up for the balance of this year and into next. We've got, call it, 1.1 million square feet -- 1.2 million square feet of lease expires coming up over the next 18 months. We are in dialogue right now with probably about half of that space in terms of tenant renewals and similarly, in terms of vacant space or space that we expect to get back. For example, we know in the second half of this year, we're going to be getting back space from U.S. Customs, which is a tenant that moved into our building after the catastrophe of 9/11 and is moving back into World Trade Center Downtown. We've got very good activity. So I don't think -- Steve, unless we want to say anything specifically about the bridge, I don't think there's anything material to talk about in terms of that number.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. I would just add a couple of things, Jamie. The huge, what we call, bulge of leasing, 7.5 million square feet that we did over the last couple of years, has accomplished several things. Number one, it basically ensured the income of the company
componenttext: Yes, sure. I would just add a couple of things, Jamie. The huge, what we call, bulge of leasing, 7.5 million square feet that we did over the last couple of years, has accomplished several things. Number one, it basically ensured the income of the company for years in the future. Second, the leasing was done at higher rents, which ensures a really huge growth. I mean, we mentioned that in our 8-K, I think, a couple of months ago, which is, I think, $216 million, something like that number. And so we ensured -- the bulge of leasing we accomplished over the last couple of years ensures the income and the rising income in the future of the company for years to come.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Jamie just to follow up on the bridge that we did in that June 7, 8-K and we used at the REITWeek meeting, when we remeasured our forecast data as of the end of Q2, we were on track with the information that we had presented previously. And so it's mo
componenttext: And Jamie just to follow up on the bridge that we did in that June 7, 8-K and we used at the REITWeek meeting, when we remeasured our forecast data as of the end of Q2, we were on track with the information that we had presented previously. And so it's moving according to what we would've expected, which isn't surprising, given that it's all contractual.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: From Sandler O'Neill, we have Alexander Goldfarb on the line.
componenttext: From Sandler O'Neill, we have Alexander Goldfarb on the line.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, just on the D.C. decision, one of the things you guys had outlined was that D.C. and New York have divergent capital needs and different return thresholds and therefore, would be difficult for D.C. to get adequate funding relative to the potential
componenttext: Steve, just on the D.C. decision, one of the things you guys had outlined was that D.C. and New York have divergent capital needs and different return thresholds and therefore, would be difficult for D.C. to get adequate funding relative to the potential New York investment. So if the decision is made to not go forward with D.C. and yet D.C. has a lot more resi, a lot more development in it, how do we reconcile that sort of concept that D.C. would need more capital and yet, the returns seemed to be better in New York?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alex, I don't -- I sort of challenge your basic assumption. The capital that is going to be invested in D.C. will be invested for as fine profits and fine returns. So I'll give you an example. I mean, we've been -- we're thrilled with this Bartlett. If yo
componenttext: Alex, I don't -- I sort of challenge your basic assumption. The capital that is going to be invested in D.C. will be invested for as fine profits and fine returns. So I'll give you an example. I mean, we've been -- we're thrilled with this Bartlett. If you all haven't seen it you ought to make a trip down there and take a look. So it's a -- it's the largest scale apartment building, the largest amenity package and the most well-received, I think, done  in the Washington District in years and years and years. From a math point of view, we created that building at a, give or take, a 7 and the value of that building, if you value the marketplace for first class apartment and brand new product, is X. If you divide those 2 numbers, there is a very satisfactory return on that capital. By the way, we built that building free and clear. We didn't use any debt to build that building. So the long and the short of it is, and I think I said in my prepared remarks, that we want to get as many of those Bartlett buildings. We want to build the next one immediately, the one after that quickly and more and more and more. So we think that, that's a very interesting business. Now we -- and we're excited about it. So we have the ingredients to make that happen. Most importantly, we have the very scarce, very important land holdings in and around the Pentagon City and in Crystal City. So if you don't have the land, you're not going anywhere. The second thing is we have the capital to do this development. Third is the return expectations are actually terrific, very satisfactory. And we have the management team that has proven the ability to develop these assets. So we are extremely optimistic about development in and around Crystal City and Pentagon City. I don't think I was bashful in my opening remarks. Now I look at this all differently. I -- if we do separate -- and by the way, we have sort of -- that's the path that we're going on. So if we do complete that, I have full intention of holding my shares in Vornado and holding my shares in Washington, call it whatever you want to call it. So I look upon it as if we're just moving from one pocket to the other. It will be well capitalized with enough capital. I'm talking about Washington-co or the SpinCo to complete its development and complete its mission, and there you have it. So I don't think it's an either/or. I think that our company will do both. If we separate the businesses, the new business will be capitalized to complete its development initiative for sure.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful, Steve. And then second question is, just on a project-specific basis, 606 Broadway, 3,000 a foot for office retail combo, can you just give us a little bit more color as far as maybe rent expectations? Or what's driving -- I mean, th
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful, Steve. And then second question is, just on a project-specific basis, 606 Broadway, 3,000 a foot for office retail combo, can you just give us a little bit more color as far as maybe rent expectations? Or what's driving -- I mean, there was land cost that was high, but what's driving it? Obviously, it's a desirable purchase for what you guys spent, but clearly there's a -- it's not your typical office retail development.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that's true. First of all, we love the spot. We love the exposure. It's like -- it's kind of like a Hollywood front. It's all front and very little depth. So it's an extremely visible -- it's an extremely, extremely visible asset and a very importan
componenttext: Well, that's true. First of all, we love the spot. We love the exposure. It's like -- it's kind of like a Hollywood front. It's all front and very little depth. So it's an extremely visible -- it's an extremely, extremely visible asset and a very important part of Manhattan. So there's that. It's actually small. The knock on this deal is why -- internally when we talk about it, it is small, small for us. But nonetheless, we thought that the asset was of such a quality that we wanted to take a shot and we did. So it's expensive per square foot. We are optimistic that the rents will justify and by the way, at the lower end of return thresholds, this is not going to be a four-bagger. But we like the prominence of the asset. It's small, which is a negative. We think it will generate rents that will justify the high cost and but it's -- we just can't predict the rents now. It's too early, we're just getting started.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: But you would think it would be sort of mid-single digits or higher than that?
componenttext: But you would think it would be sort of mid-single digits or higher than that?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: It'll be in the -- it'll be higher than mid, but certainly not double digits.
componenttext: It'll be in the -- it'll be higher than mid, but certainly not double digits.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: From Evercore ISI, we have Steve Sakwa.
componenttext: From Evercore ISI, we have Steve Sakwa.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, you mentioned -- you talked about some of the pricing comps, whether it be New York or in San Francisco. And I'm just curious how you're sort of thinking about kind of acquisitions and dispositions at this point in the cycle and whether you want to
componenttext: Steve, you mentioned -- you talked about some of the pricing comps, whether it be New York or in San Francisco. And I'm just curious how you're sort of thinking about kind of acquisitions and dispositions at this point in the cycle and whether you want to win more capital, make special dividends back to shareholders or just kind of stay tad as it is right now?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a huge omnibus question. Let me see if I can tackle it in pieces. First off, we're very, very happy with where we are -- where we stand right now. We worked very hard for the last 3, 4 years to get here. So our debt is very low. When Steve Theriot
componenttext: That's a huge omnibus question. Let me see if I can tackle it in pieces. First off, we're very, very happy with where we are -- where we stand right now. We worked very hard for the last 3, 4 years to get here. So our debt is very low. When Steve Theriot went through some of the statistics, he just said casually, well, our debt is 25%. Well, 25% is extraordinarily low. Our debt ratios are great. Our liquidity is superb, the best in the business. And so we're very pleased with that position. Having said that, we -- evidenced by our calling a series of preferreds yesterday that, we think, that it's not inappropriate to pay off high 6% securities with cash that's earning nil, which will augment and increase our earnings. It doesn't affect us from an NAV point of view, but it certainly increases our earnings. In terms of acquisitions and dispositions, I said over the last better part of 1.5 years maybe even longer that pricing in the marketplace is high, that the easy money has been made and that we look upon acquisitions with great care and scrutiny. And that continues to be the case. There has been no decline in pricing for first-quality assets that we seek. There has been some disruption in the hotel market. There hasn't been a hotel sold in Manhattan this year to-date, and the reason is that hotel business, as we've discussed already, is very soft. Obviously, the condo -- well, not obviously, but factually, the condo market is also soft -- not our condo, of course, but other people's condos. That's sort of a joke. But it's really not a joke, it's really factual. And so we are not aggressively interested in buying at the prices that are currently -- that first-class properties are currently offered. And so I think that's where we are. Now these markets are volatile, they can change. We are ready for whatever happens. And I think there you have it, my friend.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I don't know if you or David would care to do just a quick, maybe recap on street retail. There's obviously lots of concern kind of in the marketplace just over sort of the street retail business in general and kind of where rents are and some o
componenttext: Okay. And I don't know if you or David would care to do just a quick, maybe recap on street retail. There's obviously lots of concern kind of in the marketplace just over sort of the street retail business in general and kind of where rents are and some of the softness that we're seeing kind of on the lower part of Fifth. But maybe in just a quick nutshell, could you kind of go around Manhattan and sort of tell us how things are today?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. As I've said for way more than a year now, rents in Manhattan have gotten too high. So our job is to be realistic. We're not in the hope business, we're in the realistic business. And so we believe rents have gotten to the point where they are too h
componenttext: Sure. As I've said for way more than a year now, rents in Manhattan have gotten too high. So our job is to be realistic. We're not in the hope business, we're in the realistic business. And so we believe rents have gotten to the point where they are too high, and retailers are not comfortable paying those rents. So that's step one. The second part of it is our retail portfolio is pretty full -- very full, actually. We completed the last 2 big deals in town: The Victoria's Secret, huge megadeal on Fifth Avenue and the Swatch megadeal on Upper Fifth as well. So we're very pleased with our positioning. The quality of our assets is the best in town by far. Now let's go around the horn. The liquidity or the depth of the retail market has gotten very thin. So 4 years ago or 5 years ago, there might have been 3 or 4 or more retailers bidding for a particular prime space on a prime street. Right now, there's barely 1 or 2. And they're difficult to close because people -- retailers are concerned. Retailers are concerned about their own business models and less concerned about expansion. So the market is slow, retail rents or asking rents are too high. We're aware of that, and obviously, we're in the business of being realistic and making deals. And I think the soft markets are where the volumes on the street are not doing well. So Madison Avenue is soft. Lower Fifth is very soft. Upper Fifth is the volumes are fine, but the number of tenants that want to pay the rents are scarce. Times Square continues to be, I believe, the strongest, in my opinion -- the strongest market in the city. SoHo and Broadway are softish. 34th Street is doing fine. So I think that's going around the horn.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: From Stifel, we have John Guinee.
componenttext: From Stifel, we have John Guinee.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions. One, I guess, for Mitchell, you mentioned something sort of interesting about tearing down Crystal City buildings. You've got 21 buildings there, about 7 million square feet. Which ones -- or can you give us a general sense as to what would
componenttext: Two questions. One, I guess, for Mitchell, you mentioned something sort of interesting about tearing down Crystal City buildings. You've got 21 buildings there, about 7 million square feet. Which ones -- or can you give us a general sense as to what would be torn down and why? And then the next question is big picture, Steve and Steve, et cetera, you guys have done a fabulous job trying to help the Street understand future economics: 7% return on The Bartlett, $216 million NOI bridge. I think foremost on a lot of people's mind is how they actually quantify what's going on at Penn Station? When would you be in a position to do that? And what magnitude are we talking about in terms of total dollars committed?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a mouthful. Mitchell, do you want to handle the teardowns at Crystal City for a second and, I'll counter punch and then will get into the rest of John's question.
componenttext: That's a mouthful. Mitchell, do you want to handle the teardowns at Crystal City for a second and, I'll counter punch and then will get into the rest of John's question.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, John. The -- in Crystal City, there really -- if we just focus on 2 particular assets, we have a vacant asset on Crystal Drive, what we used to refer to as Mall 3, and we also have a building plaza 5 on 23rd Street. Those are -- those buildings aggr
componenttext: Sure, John. The -- in Crystal City, there really -- if we just focus on 2 particular assets, we have a vacant asset on Crystal Drive, what we used to refer to as Mall 3, and we also have a building plaza 5 on 23rd Street. Those are -- those buildings aggregate about 0.5 million square feet. Those buildings are currently, basically, empty and ready for redevelopment. So if you take those buildings and look at what we can build as a result of the Crystal City sector plan, we have almost 2 million square feet on that 500,000 plus square feet of what's built at the moment. And each of those sites could handle, ultimately, up to 1,000 apartment units. So I think, we think, that it is -- it makes all good economic sense. It makes all good sense with respect to place making and adding these apartments and in terms of what the overall mix would be.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me give you a little bit more on that same topic. So what we're going to do is take the oldest, most -- the oldest building. So the oldest buildings are 40 years old, something like that, office buildings. And we have worked with the government powers
componenttext: Let me give you a little bit more on that same topic. So what we're going to do is take the oldest, most -- the oldest building. So the oldest buildings are 40 years old, something like that, office buildings. And we have worked with the government powers that be so that in general, we can take down an older building and we build a building, which is 150% the size of that or something like that, okay? So the financial analysis goes like this. Do you take this 40-year old building or whatever and throw a significant amount of capital into that building to let it with the understanding that, that capital will have to be amortized over, pick a number, a 10-year lease and at the end of that 10-year lease, that 40 year-old building is now 50 years old. So that's one column of numbers and concept. The second column is you take it down, build a brand new residential building, which will have -- which in today's environment has the lowest exiting cap rate or value rate and that's just a matter of math. And we believe that the math shows that the teardown of the oldest buildings in favor of brand new first-class residential product is a very, very profitable and good trade. In addition to that, the -- when you get thousands of units in a tight cluster, you get a community and that creates more value. And we know how to create that community and amenitize it and make it so that people will consider this a very, very fine place to live, thinking about where it is, where it's located to, where jobs are, the metro access of it. And by the way, it is a very short walk to Pentagon City Mall, which is 1 of the top 10 malls in the country, and the Whole Foods, et cetera. So we believe that there is a -- we believe in the future of Crystal City, Pentagon City and these assets. We believe in it greatly. Now having said all that, I forgot the second question.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just the magnitude of what you're doing at Penn Station is just stunning, 4 million square feet at 1 and 2 Penn, probably teardown Hotel Pennsylvania, the Skirt, all sorts of ancillary assets that you own there, the train station and everything else. Is t
componenttext: Just the magnitude of what you're doing at Penn Station is just stunning, 4 million square feet at 1 and 2 Penn, probably teardown Hotel Pennsylvania, the Skirt, all sorts of ancillary assets that you own there, the train station and everything else. Is this $2 million or $2 billion or $20 billion in capital committed over how many years with what sort of return on cost?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so listen John, as excited as I am about what I just said about Pentagon City and Crystal City, I'm even more excited about Penn Station, okay? So really, when you think about it, you have to take it into bite-size pieces, okay? First is that the cha
componenttext: Yes, so listen John, as excited as I am about what I just said about Pentagon City and Crystal City, I'm even more excited about Penn Station, okay? So really, when you think about it, you have to take it into bite-size pieces, okay? First is that the change in the submarket and the reorientation of the market's preferences for geography in Manhattan. So we think we've got the bull's-eye, okay? So we've got $1 billion Macy's and Madison Square Garden and we sit on top of the Station. We don't sit 4 blocks away and you have to walk to it in the rain, we sit on top of it. So the basic -- and by the way, the basis that we have in our buildings is you go back in history when we started putting together the assemblage 15 years ago, our basis is pretty extraordinary. So you have all that as a backdrop. Now the way we look at it, let's take and cut it into bite-size pieces. So take 1 Penn and 2 Penn, which together are 4 million plus square feet. The average rents are published. You know what they are. They -- the first digit is a 5, and we believe that notwithstanding anything else, we can transform those buildings in this marketplace, so that the average starting rent will be higher. I don't want to get into math now, but higher than what they are now maybe even quite substantially higher. So that's a capital program, and we're going to do that and that's actually the #1 priority of what we're about. And then there's peripheral development. The retail opportunities are unique and extraordinary. And then we've got some big stuff like the Hotel Penn, which we have, I think, very intelligently delayed up until now. And so you know where you have it. We do is we take -- we leg into the project piece by piece. Now with respect to the overall amount of capital that we will be committing to this district, it's 8 million, 9 million feet.  It's huge, it's enormous, it all has very large paybacks and the most important part of it is Vornado is a fortress, financially, and has the capital ability to finance all this. So I'm not ready to put out any numbers. I'm only able to right now to talk about the concept, and I can't tell you how excited we are about this opportunity. And we're pretty excited about Crystal City and Pentagon City, too.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: From Green Street Advisers, we have Jed Reagan.
componenttext: From Green Street Advisers, we have Jed Reagan.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you talk a little bit more about the overall tempo of sales demand at 220 Central Park South, and I think you'd mentioned on the last call that you were negotiating 2 important deals. Is there any update on how those progressed?
componenttext: Can you talk a little bit more about the overall tempo of sales demand at 220 Central Park South, and I think you'd mentioned on the last call that you were negotiating 2 important deals. Is there any update on how those progressed?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: They progressed to signature. So 220 Central Park South is a very public project. The residential market, so everything that I say gets into the newspapers and whatever. So we don't really have a lot to say about 220 Central Park South other than it's sel
componenttext: They progressed to signature. So 220 Central Park South is a very public project. The residential market, so everything that I say gets into the newspapers and whatever. So we don't really have a lot to say about 220 Central Park South other than it's selling fabulously well. There's never been a project in New York that has sold as well. There was a slowdown in the marketplace for 5 or 6 months. That slowed down, and in a couple of months ago we're getting good traffic. The traffic that we're getting are extremely qualified buyers. The project is heavily skewed towards New Yorkers and Americans, and we couldn't be more delighted. The project is exceeding our expectations, both in terms of sales velocity and numerical performance.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And on the residential development plans in Crystal City and Pentagon City, how are you guys thinking about the competitive supply picture in the area? And is there enough demand to absorb what you guys and others are doing?
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And on the residential development plans in Crystal City and Pentagon City, how are you guys thinking about the competitive supply picture in the area? And is there enough demand to absorb what you guys and others are doing?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mitchell?
componenttext: Mitchell?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jed, so I think that if you look at what's happening with the Bartlett, we said that in a very short period of time, we've leased 45% of the building. So we think that a heavy amenitized building, you give somebody a really efficient, plus or minus 700 sq
componenttext: Jed, so I think that if you look at what's happening with the Bartlett, we said that in a very short period of time, we've leased 45% of the building. So we think that a heavy amenitized building, you give somebody a really efficient, plus or minus 700 square foot, one bedroom apartment and you give them a tremendous amount of amenities in the building, we think that's a real formula for success and there's real market demand for that. Having said that, in the Pentagon, Crystal City market, we really control a substantial amount of the development pipeline. There are some other projects, there are some other units, but not a significant amount over the pipeline period that we're thinking about. So we have the opportunity to both build a quality product, measure the demand, meet the demand and also modulate the supply as we see it. So we're very comfortable with our position and with our program at this point.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jed, I'm going to be a little bit more aggressive in answering. So at 220 Central Park South, which you seem to be especially interested in, we have the best site, we have the best project, we have the best design, et cetera. But as importantly, we bring
componenttext: Jed, I'm going to be a little bit more aggressive in answering. So at 220 Central Park South, which you seem to be especially interested in, we have the best site, we have the best project, we have the best design, et cetera. But as importantly, we bring a 2% cost of capital to that project. We are competing against people up and down the block, in fact, all over the place, that are paying 12% and 15% for money. As you can imagine, it's not a fair fight, okay? In Crystal City and Pentagon City, my thinking is not dissimilar to that. We own great land parcels and so I look upon that right now as being a sub-cost. We have the capital to build and develop, and this is different than office buildings. If you put up 300,000, 400,000, 500,000 square foot big office building and you catch a weak market, the building either stays vacant for year after year after year. By the way, there's dozens of example of that in the Washington region, or you have to take the price down to a number, which marks it a huge loss. Residential development is different than that, and that is if for a very marginal reduction in the monthly rate, you can get to -- you can rent and you can get absorption. So it's a totally different business. Now the other thing that's interesting is that in the office side of the light you sign a long-term lease and you're locked in to that price, good or bad, for a very long time. In the residential business, the rents will fluctuate with the market, and so over time, you're able to get what the market is -- the market thinks is the fair rent. So they're very different. We will be aggressive in building on the land that we already own there. That's our business plan.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Okay. And then just last one, a housekeeping item. On that $200-plus million of cash revenue you've laid out for the next couple of years, do you have a breakout of that revenue between the current same-store pool and the non-same-store pool?
componenttext: Sure. Okay. And then just last one, a housekeeping item. On that $200-plus million of cash revenue you've laid out for the next couple of years, do you have a breakout of that revenue between the current same-store pool and the non-same-store pool?

componenttext: It's substantially all same-store, Jed.

componenttextpreview: Which is another way of saying that we expect our same-store numbers on a cash basis to rise aggressively.
componenttext: Which is another way of saying that we expect our same-store numbers on a cash basis to rise aggressively.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: From UBS, we have Nick Yulico.
componenttext: From UBS, we have Nick Yulico.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just had one question just on the accounting for the 220 Central Park South project. So a year ago, you reversed the valuation allowance on the deferred tax asset because you were confident in generating enough income from selling the project to realize
componenttext: I just had one question just on the accounting for the 220 Central Park South project. So a year ago, you reversed the valuation allowance on the deferred tax asset because you were confident in generating enough income from selling the project to realize the tax assets. So hypothetically, you'll say the world got tougher, sales pace slowed or what have you. How should we think about how much cushion is there, so you wouldn't have to put the valuation allowance back on and create an expense against your FFO?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're all looking at each other trying to -- I mean...
componenttext: We're all looking at each other trying to -- I mean...

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We had NOLs in the taxable REIT subsidiary in which we're doing the development, which is what the reversal of the deferred -- the valuation allowance relates to. But if you look at where pricing is today based on the contracts that are in place today, ye
componenttext: We had NOLs in the taxable REIT subsidiary in which we're doing the development, which is what the reversal of the deferred -- the valuation allowance relates to. But if you look at where pricing is today based on the contracts that are in place today, yes, we think it's a very, very low risk that we'll be reversing or putting back valuation allowance on those deferred tax assets. I mean, it's very low risk.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our final question from Citi, we have a follow-up from Manny Korchman.
componenttext: And our final question from Citi, we have a follow-up from Manny Korchman.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have 2 quick follow-ups. One, Steve you've talked about the street retail business being a global business. And I'm just curious, with Brexit, does that mean you take a look at London to potentially pick off some assets over there? Or is that a nonstart
componenttext: I have 2 quick follow-ups. One, Steve you've talked about the street retail business being a global business. And I'm just curious, with Brexit, does that mean you take a look at London to potentially pick off some assets over there? Or is that a nonstarter?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I go to London a couple of times a year.
componenttext: I go to London a couple of times a year.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know that, would you go shopping for Vornado though?
componenttext: I know that, would you go shopping for Vornado though?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: The answer is that we have no current plans to invest in London.
componenttext: The answer is that we have no current plans to invest in London.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then you made a comment in your opening remarks talking about construction loans and how the difficulty in that market and then it may present opportunities for Vornado. I was wondering if you can just sort of expand a little bit on what you deem oppo
componenttext: And then you made a comment in your opening remarks talking about construction loans and how the difficulty in that market and then it may present opportunities for Vornado. I was wondering if you can just sort of expand a little bit on what you deem opportunities? Do you see yourself as a lender? Do you see yourself as being able to pick up projects for someone, take it -- financing and sort of taking over the construction? And in that vein, I guess, what property types would you be willing to do these activities? Is it condos? Is it multi? Is it retail or just traditional office?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have the full array of skill sets in here. We have a monster fortress balance sheet for capital, we have the best operating platform in the business, we have the best leasing teams in the business, we have the best construction and development teams in
componenttext: We have the full array of skill sets in here. We have a monster fortress balance sheet for capital, we have the best operating platform in the business, we have the best leasing teams in the business, we have the best construction and development teams in the business. So we have the full array of skills and strengths needed to function in good markets and in bad markets. We run our business and have run it for decades so that we are strongest when the market gets weakest because that's the time when -- that's the best time to invest. Having said that, I mean, it's pretty obvious what our preferences are. Our preferences are to be an equity player as opposed to a lender. Our preferences are to be in the income-producing property business as opposed to a onetime for-sale condo business. We're doing 220 Central Park South now. The last one we did was a dozen years ago on top of the Bloomberg. So this is not a regular business for us. And the -- so our preference is to be an owner rather than a lender. Our preference is to be an equity holder rather than a seller. The product types that we are expert in are, obviously, office and retail. So those are the 2 -- that's where our 2 main interests are. We also have a residential portfolio in Manhattan, which is performing quite well and that is a business with the correct entry point that we would invest in, although we do not have anywhere near the scale in that business that we have in office and it retail. So having said that, we're open for business every day. And we have a history over the years of making some of our very best deals when there's some level of distress or disruption in the lending market, people get overleveraged, et cetera, so we are very alert and looking for that as we speak.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And maybe if I could just have you answer one quick last one. You've made massive strides in simplification of the company and significant strides in terms of disclosure, having these quarterly calls is a massive step by providing The Street with updates.
componenttext: And maybe if I could just have you answer one quick last one. You've made massive strides in simplification of the company and significant strides in terms of disclosure, having these quarterly calls is a massive step by providing The Street with updates. I'm curious as your thoughts in terms of potentially have evolved on providing earnings guidance with the company being much more simplified in terms of in items? Is that something that's on the table? Or just you just will never sort of do the sort of guide The Street in terms of earnings?

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't want to speculate on that. I mean, I read Warren Buffett's position, I read the very interesting treatise on governance that came out a couple of a weeks ago by some industry leader that votes for investment side. There's 2 sides and 3 sides of th
componenttext: I don't want to speculate on that. I mean, I read Warren Buffett's position, I read the very interesting treatise on governance that came out a couple of a weeks ago by some industry leader that votes for investment side. There's 2 sides and 3 sides of that issue and I don't want to get -- I don't want to comment on it because obviously, we talk about it a little bit inside, not a lot a little bit. But I really don't want to speculate as to whether we -- even what we think about it. We're not unhappy with where we are. I appreciate your comment that we have made massive strides in simplification in disclosure, et cetera and we agree with you and I think I'll just leave it at that.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just thinking about, you've had a couple of quarters now where the earnings have missed The Street, and there's very good rational reasons to point those out. I just wonder if there was a little bit more specifics in terms of what was coming that everyone
componenttext: Just thinking about, you've had a couple of quarters now where the earnings have missed The Street, and there's very good rational reasons to point those out. I just wonder if there was a little bit more specifics in terms of what was coming that everyone knew you wouldn't get an adverse market reaction to for the result.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I can't tell you how -- I agree with you. We delve, ourselves, into it a bit. From the last couple of quarters, we missed The Street, but we never told The Street anything. So The Street is missing itself. So that's the first thing. I can tell you th
componenttext: Yes, I can't tell you how -- I agree with you. We delve, ourselves, into it a bit. From the last couple of quarters, we missed The Street, but we never told The Street anything. So The Street is missing itself. So that's the first thing. I can tell you that I'm really -- I'm not nuts about beat a penny, raise a penny culture and we're trying to avoid that. I understand what you are saying. We have thought about it, as I said, a little bit, and I don't have anything more to say about it.

headline: Vornado Realty Trust, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll now turn it back to Stephen Roth for closing remarks.
componenttext: We'll now turn it back to Stephen Roth for closing remarks.

componenttext: Thank you, everybody. We learn from these calls, and we appreciate the dialogue. And we'll be back on, I guess, next quarter, which is when?

componenttext: November 1.

componenttext: November 1. So we'll see everybody before then I'm sure, but we'll be back on the phone with you all on November 1. Thank you.
